abstract.text: To improve understanding of severe group A streptococcal (GAS) disease in Europe and achieve an integrated picture of these infections, the Strep-EURO project comprising 11 countries started in September 2002. A European case definition for severe invasive GAS disease was agreed upon amongst all participants. In order to obtain nation-wide coverage, information on the project was given to infectioncontrol units, relevant hospitals and microbiological laboratories. A clinical questionnaire containing background identification data, possible predisposing factors, portal of entry of infection, epidemiological risk factors, source of isolate, clinical condition, complications and outcome, was used for each case. Enhanced surveillance of GAS invasive disease commenced on 1 January 2003 for a two-year period. By July 2004, over 5000 invasive GAS isolates were collected of which more than 3000 were from UK. The disease incidence rate in the different countries seems to vary from 2 to 3.8 per 100,000 population. Molecular methods for typing and clonal identification of clinical isolates were used. An overall increase of new invasive types is noted. Higher emm types (77, 78, 81, 82, 83, 87, 89) were thus reported from almost all partners, in contrast to types 1, 3 and 28 being predominant for several years. In Sweden, for example, emm types 81 and 89 accounted for a majority of isolates. This unusual change of type distribution in Europe is of serious concern. A high level of MLS antibiotic resistance in some countries (France, Italy) and very frequent tetracycline resistance in almost all countries was noted. Furthermore, pathogenic aspects of severe GAS disease, such as proteolytic activation of the contact system, and selected virulence factors, such as surface proteins and superantigens, were investigated. A new Strep-EURO website (www.strep-euro.lu.se) was constructed and updated regularly. The website is linked with other, relevant websites and contains both an "intra-net" site accessible to those persons participating within the project, and an "extra-net" site for the general public. A central database for severe GAS cases, receiving clinical and laboratory information from the local databases was also established. Strep-EURO has now created a European network for epidemiological analysis and surveillance of severe streptococcal disease in ten EU and one Associated Countries.

Objectives: Strep-EURO is an EU FP-5 funded programme designed to greatly enhance our understanding of severe group A streptococcal (GAS) infections. We present early epidemiological findings gathered by the UK team.

Methods: Enhanced population-based surveillance was implemented in the UK in part fulfilment of the strep-EURO objectives. Two pre-existing data sources were reconciled to maximise case ascertainment: routine national surveillance based on local microbiological investigation; isolate referral to the national reference laboratory. Individual cases were followed-up to capture clinical and epidemiological information. Preliminary data relating to cases diagnosed in 2003 were analysed to determine the burden, clinical presentation and risk factors for disease and microbiological characteristics of strains.

Results: A total of 2064 cases were reported by 223 laboratories across England and Wales, an overall incidence of 3.93 per 100,000 population. A clear seasonal pattern was apparent, with peak incidence from mid-March to -April. The observed incidence in males was higher than in females (RR = 1.29; 95% CI: 1.18-1.41). Twelve percent of cases occurred in children (<18 years). Ninety percent of cases were bacteraemic, 10% had septic arthritis and 9% pneumonia. Other clinical manifestations included toxic shock-like syndrome (6%), necrotising fasciitis (5%), puerperal sepsis (3%) and meningitis (1%). Skin lesions/wounds were the most common predisposing factor, with injecting drug use reported in 30% of cases; 28% had no predisposing/risk factors identified. Nineteen percent of cases were reported as having died within 7 days of diagnosis. Local microbiological analysis identified 4% of GAS isolates as erythromycin resistant. Type characterisation of strains using a combination of serological and sequencing techniques revealed over 35 M-types, with M1, M3 and M87most common.

Conclusion: Enhanced surveillance of severe GAS infections is beginning to yield information of value in targeting public health initiatives. Our estimation of disease burden has been substantially improved, as has our understanding of the role of specific risk factors such as injecting drug use. Comparison with other European countries will further our understanding of these data.

The objectives of our study were to create an animal model of aerosol infection with Coxiella burnetiiphase I (Nine Mile strain) and to determine the pathogenic potential of the organism in C57BL/6 mice exposed to an infectious aerosol with an inoculum of 2 × 10 9 bacteria. Mice (N = 15) were inoculated using an aerosolisation device for 45 min. Five mice were sacrificed at day 0, 7 and 14 of the study. C. burnetii detection was performed by Light Cycler Nested PCR assay in lungs and blood samples. Antibodies to phases I and II C. burnetii whole cell antigens were determined in the sera by immunofluorescence testing. Inflammatory reactions in lungs and spleen samples were investigated by histological and immunohistological analysis. C. burnetii was detected by genomic amplification in the blood of mice sacrificed at day 7 and in all lung samples. All infected mice sacrificed at day 14 had developed antibodies to C. burnetii phases I and II antigens (titer of 1:1600). Inflammatory infiltrates were seen in the lungs of mice sacrificed at day 7 and 14, bacteria were detected by immunohistochemistry in the macrophages cells. In our study, we demonstrated that the infection first resulted in an interstitial pneumonia. C. burnetii was then released and may spread hematogenously to other organs. As a conclusion, this murine model of aerosol-induced experimental Q fever is the first step for studies on acute Q fever, especially in terms of pathogenicity.

body_text.text: A total of 30 unrelated episodes of nosocomial infections involved 50 patients (1-6 patients per episode). The 32 invasive nosocomial infections accounted for 13% of the total of 249 invasive streptococcal infections reported during the same period. Predisposing factors were mostly surgical operation or child delivery. Post-surgical infections included: superficial and deep-tissue infections, such as soft-tissue necrosis, abcesses, or erysipelas; pneumonia, peritonitis, bacteremia, with or without toxic shock syndrom and death. Post-partum infections were suspected as nosocomial, although evidence of hospital acquisition were rarely obtained. Bacteremia, endometritis or peritonitis occured early after vaginal delivery or caesarian. They were less frequently associated with malignant outcome.

body_text.text: More than 10 different emm types were represented among the 50 S. pyogenes isolates. Three predominant emm types account for 66% of the virulent strains: emm1 (17%), emm4 (19%) and emm28 (30%). Strains of emm type 1, mostly associated with invasive infections, toxic shock, necrotizing fasciitis and death, were the sole responsible for five episodes; emm4 strains, mostly associated with post-surgical infections, were responsible for five episodes; and emm28, mostly associated with puerperal sepsis, were responsible for six episodes. In addition one cluster of six cases of puerperal sepsis involved these three different emm types simultaneously.

Guidelines include, inter alia, isolation of the patient and reinforcement of infection control practices in each case of post-partum or -surgical infection.

body_text.text: A total of 51 invasive GAS isolates from 29 male and 22 female children hospitalised between January 2003 to June 2004, in the 'Aghia Sophia' and the 'P and A Kyriakou' Children's Hospitals in Athens were examined. The isolates were characterised by M/emm type, sensitivity to penicillin, erythromycin, clindamycin and tetracycline (using the Kirby-Bauer and E-test methods), and identification of the streptococcal exotoxins (spe) and antimicrobial resistance genes. The mean age of the patients was 4 years (age range 17 months to 14 years). A total of 20 patients presented with varicella infection and were admitted to hospital on the sixth day (mean average) after the eruption of the vesicles (overall admission range 1-17 days). From the available data on 26 children, the mean duration of hospitalisation was 12.4 days (range 1 h to 42 days); three of 51 children were admitted to the ICU, one presented with both varicella and meningitis and died within the first hour of admission. A total of 16/51 patients (31.4%) had bacteraemia (nine with varicella); 14 had cellulitis (eight with varicella). Other clinical manifestations included septic arthritis (6), osteomyelitis (3), pneumonia/empyema (3), STSS (2), necrotising fasciitis/myositis (2), meningitis (1), brain abscess (1) and upper respiratory abscess (1). The primary focus of infection was the upper respiratory tract in 18 of the 51 children (35.3%) followed by the skin (15.7%).

body_text.text: The immunopathogenesis of invasive group A streptococcal (GAS) infections involves a complex interplay between bacterial virulence factors and host factors. Cytokines elicited by bacterial superantigens have been suggested to play a central role in severe systemic clinical manifestations of gram-positive sepsis. Analyses of in vivo and in vitro cytokine responses in patients with severe (streptococcal toxic shock syndrome and/or necrotizing fasciitis) or nonsevere (no toxic shock or deep-tissue involvement) invasive GAS infection revealed a direct correlation between cytokine responses and severity of invasive disease. Significantly elevated frequencies of pro-inflammatory cytokines were observed in acute phase peripheral blood mononuclear cells from severe cases as compared to non-severe cases. Analyses of tissue biopsies from patients with GAS tissue infections revealed a similar correlation between the magnitudes of pro-inflammatory cytokines, in particular Th1 cytokines, and severity of infection. This difference in in vivo cytokine responses during acute phase could be reproduced when paired age and sex-matched severe and non-severe cases infected with a clonal GAS strain were tested in vitro during their convalescent phase for immune response to culture supernatants from their infecting isolate. These findings indicated that the propensity to be either a high or a low responder to superantigens is a stable feature of the host, which may contribute to severity of disease. Further studies revealed that specific HLA class II haplotypes conferred protection from severe disease, whereas others increased the risk of severe disease. Functional analysis revealed that the risk HLA types promoted significantly higher cytokine responses against GAS superantigens than did the protective ones. Taken together the studies show that HLA class II molecules that influence the magnitude of immune responses to GAS superantigens play a pivotal role in determining the outcome of invasive GAS infection.

body_text.text: The clinical significance of MRSA

Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) is replacing its susceptible predecessor across the world. Whilst this can be perceived as an inevitable consequence of antimicrobial consumption, acquisition by the individual, and collectively for hospitals, has important implications regarding healthcare and societal costs for every country affected. The crux of the problem lies with the difficulties in managing colonised and infected patients, as well as the organism's propensity for survival and spread. Such difficulties have created opposing opinions on whether there is any point funding rigorous infection control activities, when many countries continue to witness a persistent increase.
body_text.section: Dancer S, Leonard A. Scottish Centre for Infection and Environmental Health, Glasgow,UK

body_text.text: Tempting though it is to abandon search and destroy policies for MRSA, there are convincing reasons why control should remain a priority. Managerial interests could be directed towards the financial consequences of MRSA since there is robust evidence demonstrating cost-benefits for hospitals from various control initiatives. We should also consider the cost to an individual patient as well as society itself. Some of these are non-calculable. Savings can be obtained from both general and specific control interventions-the former encompassing estimates such as reduction in hospital bed-days or overall costs of hospital-acquired infection; the latter alludes to hand-washing programmes, screening or antibiotic prescribing. Hospitals with rising numbers of MRSA patients experience an increasing financial burden, which influences both healthcare policies and overall societal costs. As with the indefinable impact upon human health and well-being, these will escalate without managerial and political commitment. Before the introduction of any clinical improvement programme, resources must first be released before implementation. From the evidence presented, it is clear that control efforts will not only pay for themselves, but would generate other direct and indirect benefits to individual patients and society as a whole.

Laboratoire de Parasitologie-Mycologie,G.H. Pitié-Salpêtrière, Paris, France Purpose: Detection of the Aspergillus galactomannan in serum by the Platelia ® Aspergillus enzyme immunoassay (EIA) is a useful tool for the early diagnosis of invasive aspergillosis (IA). Recently, false-positive tests have been reported in patients at risk for IA as related to the use of piperacillin-tazobactam (PPR-TZB). Since we found that other hemisynthetic penicillins may cross-react with this EIA, we sought to study the kinetics of antigenemia in patients receiving these drugs and to understand how false EIA positivity may be circumvented.

Methods: We reviewed 65 patients for which at least one positive serum (cut-off at 0.8 ng/ml) was detected in absence of IA from June 2003 to july 2004. The antibiotic regimen was prospectively investigated, and drug batches tested with the Aspergillus EIA.

Results: Antibiotherapy including either amoxicillin (AMX), amoxicillin-clavulanic acid (AMX-CLV) or PPR-TZB was recorded among 62 patients. Follow-up of antigenemia in 26 patients revealed two types of kinetics, each observed with either drug, including per os AMX-CLV. In the first type, values above 3 ng/ml were obtained within the first 24 h and remained high whatever the time lapse between serum sampling and infusion period was (0.5-8 h). Upon the last dose, decline and negativity occurred at 24 and 72-96 h, respectively. In the second type, values were lower (1.0-2.6 ng/ml) with shorten delay to negativity. Whereas all drug batches tested positive, the deduced antigen concentrations at peak serum drug concentration were at least a tenfold lower than that obtained from patient sera.

Conclusion: AMX or AMX-CLA can generate false EIA positivity like PPR-TZB whatever the formulation is. While testing every batch is demanding and costly, it is the only indicator of a possible false EIA positivity since testing serum collected prior to the next antibiotic dose does not prevent from it. Our data suggest that EIA positivity presumably due to the fungal galactomannan present in certain batches of these hemisynthetic penicillins, is amplified by serum components which nature remains to be determined. Expertise of the biologist is important for clinicians to avoid misleading diagnosis of IA, useless antifungal therapy or antibiotic switching.

Brun S a , Dalle F d , Saulnier P c , Renier G b , Bonnin A d , Chabasse D a , Bouchara JP a . a Groupe d'Etudes des Interactions Hôte-parasite, France, b Respiratory-deficient mutants of Candida glabrata, which present a reduced susceptibility to azole antifungals, are easily induced in vitro by exposure to azole drugs or ethidium bromide and may be selected in vivo in patients undergoing fluconazole prophylaxis or therapy. The present study was therefore conducted in order to define the pathogenicity of these petite mutants. To do this, two wild-type isolates of C. glabrata were compared with their respective fluconazole or ethidium bromide-induced petite mutants, regarding the carbohydrate and protein composition of the cell wall, as well as their surface physical properties and expression of CgEPA1 gene encoding an adhesin, but also their adherence capabilities and their virulence in mice. Thus, flow cytometric analysis of cell wall carbohydrates using several fluorescent lectins showed an increased binding of mutant cells to concanavalin A compared with their parent isolates, suggesting a greater availability or an increased amount of glucose-mannose residues at the cell surface in petite mutants. Likewise, quantitative differences were shown by SDS-PAGE in the surface proteins of blastoconidia between parent and mutant isolates. Regarding the surface physical properties, no significant differences were seen in the electrophoretic mobility determined by microelectrophoresis, but two-phase partitioning using hexadecane as the organic phase revealed a lower hydrophobicity for all petite mutants compared with parent isolates. Moreover, mutant cells exhibited an important overexpression of the gene CgEPA1 as revealed by real-time reverse transcription-PCR compared with their parent isolates, but the adherence capacities to Caco-2 cells, a human enterocyte cell line, were not significantly different. Finally, as suggested by their slower growth, petite mutants were less virulent than parent isolates in an experimental model of systemic infection using immunocompetent mice. Together these results suggest that one can disregard C. glabrata petite mutants clinically. However, due to their markedly decreased virulence, these mutants may constitute valuable tools for the characterization of virulence factors of this yeast, and proteomic studies of the changes associated with petite mutations are now in progress.

body_text.text: Patients and methods: Mycological screening were performed on patients admitted in a surgical intensive care unit (SICU), at admittance then weekly until discharge, during a 24-month prospective survey. Patients with corrected colonization index ¡Ý 0.4 received pre-emptive therapy (fluconazole 400 mg/day for two weeks). Study focused on C.g and C.k epidemiology and origin of C.g/C.k colonization (imported versus SICU-acquired). Molecular typing of C.k isolates (microsatellite polymorphism and IGR-PCR) was undertaken to identify possible patient-to-patient C.k transmission.

Results: C.g and C.k represented respectively 13.2% and 4.4% of yeast isolates and colonized respectively, 12.4% and 6.0% of 745 SICU patients included for analysis. One hundred and twenty out of 133 C.g/C.k colonized patients presented imported colonization whereas the 13 remaining patients were not apparently colonized at admittance. However, only one out of these 13 patients previously received pre-emptive fluconazole therapy. Molecular typing showed that each patient had his own specific C.kstrain and noC.k cross-contamination could be demonstrated.

Discussion: Implementation of pre-emptive strategy in SICU did not open on acquisition of fluconazole resistant Candida species during SICU-stay of the patients. These reassuring data should be completed by a long-term epidemiological survey and molecular study on C.g transmission.

body_text.text: A 31-year-old man with congenital deafness and a 12 year history of type 1 diabetes mellitus complicated by diabetic retinopathy of the right eye was admitted to the hospital in August 2003 with suspected facial erysipelas and impaired vision in his left eye. On admission his temperature was 38.4 • C and his HbA1c was >10%. Empiric therapy with amoxicillin/clavulanic acid was started. One day later, his vision further deteriorated because of occlusion of central retinal veins and arteries. Staphylococcus aureus was isolated from nasal swabs, and sinusitis with orbital cellulitis was suspected; however, biopsies of orbital fat obtained during decompression surgery showed histological evidence of zygomycosis. Enucleation of the left eye was performed and AMB 1 mg/kg/day was started (baseline serum creatinine = 76 umol/L). Despite four surgical revisions and >5 weeks of AMB, there was no clinical improvement or eradication of the fungus. MRI showed infiltration of the sinuses. Development of AMB-related renal failure (serum creatinine = 231 umol/L) necessitated switching therapy to liposomal AMB 5 mg/kg/day; however, the zygomycosis continued to worsen. Because of the patient's severely impaired vision and deafness, communication with the patient became difficult.

The patient was enrolled in an open-label compassionate treatment use protocol in November 2003. POS 200 mg four times daily was started. During the first 3 weeks of therapy, involvement of the cavernous sinus and optic chiasma were noted. After 8 weeks of therapy, the zygomycosis became stable and there were no signs of progressive periorbital fungal infiltration. MRI showed no further progression of the disease. POS treatment was completed after 26 weeks. One year after the diagnosis, the patient has regained the ability to communicate and care for himself. The successful outcome observed in this patient indicates that POS may be an effective treatment for zygomycosis.

Talon D a , Wollner A b , Bonin S b , Bertrand X a . a Hygiène Hospitalière, CHU, France, b CLS Bellevaux, Besançon, France Whereas the infectious MRSA risk is considered as key quality indicator of the level of hand hygiene practices in healthcare settings, long-term-care facilities (LTCF) appeared very powerful in this field. Indeed, during a 3-year surveillance in facilities of Franche-Comté region, incidence of MRSA colonisations/infections was 0.09 and 0.9, respectively, in LTCF and acute care facilities. The objectives of this study were to establish the frequency of MRSA acquisition in a 250 beds-LTCF and to discuss the roles of screening for MRSA carriers, the type of isolation to be implemented and the efficiency of chemical decontamination. The combination of the prevalence of MRSA carriage and MRSA screening upon admission allowed us to evaluate the MRSA acquisition risk according to the characteristics of the patients and the inter-hospital transfers. The prevalence study showed that 15.2% of the patients were MRSA carriers. On the admission, 23.3% of the patients were positive with MRSA. Among MRSA-free patients on admission, without any transfer, 14% became positive for MRSA, all had lost their autonomy. Chemical decolonisation (nasal mupirocin + cutaneous chlorexidine) was efficient for 22 patients out of 25 (88%). In LTCF, the frequency of MRSA cross-transmission could not be evaluated on the basis of clinical samples. MRSA acquisition occurred exclusively among totally dependent patients. Thus, technical isolation rules should be respected when carrying out treatments, the efficacy of such isolation being unaffected by the mobility of patients and their "resocialisation". Chemical decolonisation was efficient and made it possible to reduce the number of days of technical isolation. Given the increase in morbidity associated with MRSA observed in numerous hospitals, the emergence of a community-based disease linked to these strains and the emergence of glycopeptide-resistant strains, the application of a voluntary strategy including screening, isolation and decolonization in R-CCF appears to be an urgent matter of priority.

Hôpital Bichat-Claude Bernard, Paris, France Background and objectives: Despite the increasing incidence of MRSA, little is known about MRSA acquisition outside of the intensive care units. A prospective observational study was designed to assess (i) the prevalence and factors associated with MRSA on admission to four high-risk acute care wards (acute geriatric, dermatology, diabetology, and septic surgical wards), and (ii) incidence and risk factors for MRSA acquisition.

body_text.text: Methods: During 5 months, a nasal swab was obtained at admission to, and discharge from these units, together with a skin swab of chronic skin break (CSB), if present. At admission, patients (Pts) with at least one risk factor for MRSA were screened: transfer from another health-care institution or receiving home care, history of hospitalization in the last 12 months (Hosp), prior MRSA carriage, poor chronic health status or CSB. After admission, parameters obtained were workload (as assessed with the SIIPS score) and duration of unit stay (DUS). Contact precautions were used for MRSA-positive Pts.

body_text.text: Results: Of the 1193 admitted Pts, 846 were included (first admission during the study, hospital stay >48 h, and admission to the study unit <3 days. after hospital admission). MRSA prevalence was 6.6% (56/846, 22/56 previously known as MRSA carriers). Without admission screening, 29/56 (52%) MRSA carriers would have been missed. body_text.text: Epidemiology and antimicrobial resistance of pneumococci in Greece: a preliminary report of the Hellenic Study for the susceptibility of Purpose: To present preliminary data of an ongoing nation-wide surveillance study on the susceptibility of Streptococcus pneumoniae strains from nasopharyngeal colonization (NPC) or invasive pneumococcal disease.

Methods: Nasopharyngeal sampling from healthy children (2-6 years old) attending day-centers was performed from February to May 2004. Collection of clinical isolates started in January 2004 and will end in December 2004. Pneumococci were identified by use of optochin sensitivity, bile solubility and slide agglutination (Pneumolatex) assays. Susceptibility testing was performed for penicillin (PG), cefuroxime (CXM), ceftriaxone (CXT), erythromycin (ERY), tetracycline (TET), cotrimoxazole (COT), levofloxacin (LE) and moxifloxacin (MX) by E-test. NCCLS methodology and breakpoints for intermediate resistance (IR) and resistance (R) were used.

Results: A total of 886 NPC pneumococcal strains was isolated from 2927 children, yielding 30.26% mean pneumococcal carriage over the sampling period. Twenty-eight clinical strains were also collected until Only nine NPC PG resistant strains (out of the total 461 studied, i.e. 1.95%) had an MIC > 2 g/ml (range 2-4). No resistance to respiratory quinolones was observed. PG + EM R strains account for 11% of the total. Susceptibility patterns varied among different geographic departments. For clinical strains, rates were as follows: PG IR 14.3% and PG R 14.3%, XT R 3.6% and EM R 33.3%. No quinolone resistance was observed as well.

Conclusions: Data suggest an increasing trend in the resistance rates for both penicillin and erythromycin. Geographic variation of resistance may reflect climatologic conditions or antibiotic consumption behaviour, and warrants further investigation. Despite increasing trends in resistance, the very low number of strains beyond clinical resistance cut-offs (MIC for PG > 4 g/ml) render ␤-lactams still potent agents against pneumococcal disease.

Persistence of animal and human glycopeptide resistant enterococci on Norwegian poultry farms formerly exposed to avoparcin is associated with a widespread plasmid-mediated vanA-element Johnsen P b , Sørum M a , Sletvold H b , Rosvoll T b , Østerhus JI b , Kruse H a , Nielsen K b , Simonsen GS b , Sundsfjord A b . a Norwegian Zoonosis Center, National Veterinary institute, Oslo, Norway, b Microbiology and Virology, University of Tromsø, Tromsø, Norway

The evolutionary processes responsible for long-term persistence of glycopeptide resistant Enterococcus faecium (GREF) in non-selective environments were addressed by genetic analyses of animal and human E. faecium populations on two Norwegian poultry farms previously exposed to avoparcin. A total of 222 faecal GREF (N = 136) and glycopeptide susceptible (N = 86) E. faecium (GSEF) isolates were obtained from farmers and poultry on three separate occasions in 1998-1999. Pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) and plasmid DNA analyses discerned 22 GREF and 32 GSEF PFGE types within shifting polyclonal animal and human E. faecium populations and transferable plasmid mediated vanA-resistance. Examples of dominant persistent GREF PFGE types supported the notion that environmentally well-adapted GREF-types may counteract the reversal of resistance. PFGE analyses, sequencing of thepurK housekeeping gene, and partial typing of the vanA-containing Tn1546 suggested a common animal and human reservoir of glycopeptide resistance. Inverse PCR amplification and sequence analyses targeting the right end of the Tn1546-plasmid junction fragment strongly indicated the presence of a common single Tn1546-plasmid mediated element in 20 of 22 GREF PFGE types. This observation was further strengthened by vanY-Z hybridization analyses of plasmid DNA as well as the finding of physical linkage between Tn1546 and a putative postsegregation killing system (PSK) in seven GREF PFGE types. In conclusion, our observations suggest that the molecular unit of persistence of glycopeptide resistance is a common mobile plasmid mediated vanA-containing element within a polyclonal GREF-population changing over time. In addition we propose that "plasmid addiction systems" may contribute to persistence of GREF in non-selective environments.

Segonds C c , Clavel-Batut P c , Eydieux-Laporte K c , Le Thomas-Bories I c , Bingen E a , Mariani P a , Brahimi N a , Ravilly S b , Chabanon G c . a Service de Microbiologie, Paris, Hôpital Robert Debré, Paris, b Vaincre la Mucoviscidose, Paris, c Laboratoire de Bactériologie-Hygiène, France, Hôpital Rangueil, Toulouse, France Methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) is a major cause for epidemiological concern due to its spread through health-care settings, its increasing prevalence in the community, and the emergence of decreased susceptibility to glycopeptides. In patients with cystic fibrosis (CF), S. aureus (SA) is usually the first pathogen recovered from the respiratory tract, and the rate of MRSA has increased during the last decade. The respective prevalences of methicillin-susceptible SA (MSSA) and MRSA in the French CF population have been established at 54.6% and 10.9% in 2001 (Observatoire National de la Mucoviscidose). The present study was undertaken to assess the characteristics of the MRSA-colonised CF population and to analyse the antimicrobial susceptibilities and genetic relationships of isolates. One hundred and eleven MRSA colonised patients from 17 CF Centers in 11 regions were included. The mean age of acquisition is 13.7 years (<1-37); colonisation is chronic in 65% cases. Of 82 documented cases, 54 (66%) had been hospitalized during the prior year, whereas 28 (34%) had not; 40 (49%) received an antistaphylococcal antibiotic shortly (<30 days) after MRSA diagnosis, mainly cotrimoxazole (19 patients) or pristinamycin (11 patients); a glycopeptide has been used in five patients. Among 116 non-redundant isolates, most (88: 75.9%) were susceptible to gentamicin and resistant to tobramycin and amikacin. Pristinamycin, cotrimoxazole, fusidic acid and rifampicin were effective on 100%, 96.5%, 78.4% and 78.4% of isolates, respectively. Seven gentamicin resistant isolates exhibited a reduced susceptibility to glycopeptides. One hundred and fourteen isolates recovered from 109 patients were compared by use of pulse-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE), and classified in 41 types: 26/41 types were unique, whereas 15 included two to 27 isolates. Two types were predominant, involving 23 and 14 patients, in eight and six regions, respectively. In 8/17 CF Centres, several patients harboured the same type.

In addition, 14 seroconversion panels were tested with the VIDAS DUO Ultra and AxSYM HIV Ag/Ab Combo assays. In addition, given its excellent sensitivity and the availability of independent results for the antigen and the antibody assays, the test is appropriated to the early detection of HIV seroconversion.

body_text.text: Trak-c is a new diagnostic tool in the management of therapeutic follow-up of HIV/HCV co-infected patients treated for chronic hepatitis C Pivert A a , Payan C a , Lunel Fabiani F a , Morand P b . a Laboratoire de Virologie, CHU Angers, Angers, France, b Laboratoire de Virologie,CHU Grenoble, Grenoble, France Background: trak-C, developed by Ortho-Clinical Diagnostics TM , is an assay to quantitate total Hepatitis C Virus (HCV) core antigen in serum. The evaluation of trak-C assay was realised by comparison of the viral kinetics of both markers: total HCV core antigen (trak-C) and HCV viral load (Versant HCV RNA 3.0, Bayer Diagnostics). To evaluate this quantitative assay, we studied 204 patients from RIBAVIC protocol (approximately 1100 samples for each assay).

Methods: RIBAVIC is a therapeutic, multicenter, randomised trial comparing the efficacy of two treatments for chronic hepatitis C: Interferon a2b (IFN) 3 MU × 3 week and ribavirin 800 mg/day versus pegylated interferon (PEG-IFN) 1.5 g/kg/week and ribavirin 800 mg/day during 48 weeks, in co-infected HIV-HCV patients naïve of HCV treatment. Patients were tested at week (W) 0, 2, 4, 12, 24, 48 and 72. Sustained virological responders have a negative PCR 6 months after the end of treatment (W72).

Results: Correlation of core antigen quantitation by trak-C and RNA quantitation by HCV RNA v3.0 was excellent (r = 0.94, p < 0.01). We found a very good correlation between decrease of viral load and negativation of HCV core antigen under treatment: a 2 log IU/ml decline after W4 was significantly correlated with a negative HCV core antigen and sustained response (r = 0.64, p < 0,01). After W4, 69.5% of sustained responders had an RNA decrease >2 log IU/ml and 85.2% had a negative HCV core antigen (49.1% and 69% after W2). The positive and negative predictive values of response to the treatment at W4 were respectively, 57.7% and 85.4% for viral load reduction >2 log IU/ml, 56.5% and 91.1% for negative HCV core antigen, 88.9% and 79.1% for negative PCR (p < 0.0001). When we studied the delay of negativation under treatment, it appears that responders (delay = 36.7 weeks, n = 58) presents negative PCR for longer time than relapsers (delay = 28.6 weeks, n = 15) (p > 0.05). This result must be confirmed with more relapsers.
Conclusions: Total HCV Core Antigen appears to be a new tool for monitoring patients with HCV-HIV co-infection and an early predictor of response to the treatment.

Human herpesvirus-6 (HHV-6) is an ubiquitous and highly seroprevalent virus in the general population. Two variants A and B of the HHV-6 have been identified on the basis of genotypic and phenotypic differences, but many questions are pending concerning their specific epidemiological and pathogenic properties. Although both variants may infect human, HHV-6 variant B accounts for the majority of clinical manifestations during primary infection and reactivation (encephalitis, hematopoiesis disorders, febrile cutaneous rash), whereas the variant A has been occasionally associated to pathologies (fetal hydrops, encephalitis). Both variants may be detected in lymph nodes and lung tissue without clinical impact. The aim of our study was to develop a rapid, sensitive and specific method to identify HHV-6 variants in different types of biological samples, especially in case of mixed infection. We evaluated a technique adapted from the real-time quantitative method previously developed in our laboratory, which included the change of the consensual reverse primer into two variant-specific primers. Five different strains of HHV-6 variant A (GS, SIE, TAN) and variant B (HST, MAR) have been used either separately or mixed (variants A and B) in various proportions. For both variants, the sensitivity was 10 genomic copies. Regarding specificity, human DNA or other herpesvirus DNA (HSV, VZV, HCMV, EBV, HHV-7, HHV-8) were not amplified. In case of mixed infections, one variant (A or B) could be detected in the presence of more than 10 3 -fold more copies of the other one. Various biological samples including peripheral blood mononuclear cells, saliva, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue biopsies, bone marrow and oral mucosal swabs have been tested. For the samples for which a previous identification of HHV-6 variant was performed using a reference method, we obtained a total concordance. HHV-6 variant B was mainly identified and variant A or mixed infection could be evidenced. Of note, variant A infection was observed in case of neurological disorders. This new method constitutes a useful tool to identify HHV-6 variants in various biological samples, even in the case of mixed infections. We have also evidenced a neurological tropism of the variant A associated to encephalitis in infant or adult.

Department of Microbiology, Medical School, University of Ioannina, Ioannina, Greece PCR is becoming the new standard for virological diagnosis of the infections of the central nervous system (CNS). Use of this test has been shown to have the impact on patient management as measured by shortened patient stays and reduction of empirical therapy administration. This study aimed at reporting our experience over the last years in the detection and management of herpesviruses and enteroviruses (EVs) induced CNS infections by using PCR assays. A total of 127 consecutive CSF specimens from patients hospitalized between April 2001 and August 2004 to the University Hospital of Ioannina with clinically suspected viral CNS infection were tested for the presence of the herpesvirus and EV genome using Herpes Consensus and Enterovirus Consensus assays (Argene Biosoft, France). The Herpes Consensus assay allowed the simultaneously amplification of the six major herpesviruses in a single PCR: herpes simplex virus 1 and 2 (HSV1, HSV2), varicella-zoster virus (VZV), cytomegalovirus (CMV), Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6). The Enterovirus Consensus assay allowed the reverse transcription and amplification of all 64 prototypes of EVs. Amplified products were detected by microplate hybridization. The specificity and sensitivity of the assays were evaluated with samples from three external control proficiency panels. Overall, 42 (33%) of the CSF samples tested were positive in the PCR. HSV1 was detected in one adult (0.8%) with encephalitis, VZV was detected in one adult (0.8%) with meningitis, and EVs were detected in 40 children (31.5%) with meningitis and/or encephalitis. None of the specimens tested was positive for HSV2, CMV, EBV and HHV-6 genomes. From the 42 positive CSF specimens, none presented herpesvirus and EVs coinfection in the CNS The precise diagnosis of viral CNS infections was available within 24-48 h, which allowed for a better clinical management of the patients in terms of the duration of hospitalization and the specific therapeutic intervention. In conclusion the Consensus PCR methodology enabled the rapid detection of the herpesviruses and EVs in CSF and provided a reliable, noninvasive tool in the diagnosis of viral CNS infections.

body_text.text: Role of the mutator phenotype in experimental osteomyelitis due to Staphylococcus aureus and in antibiotic resistance Daurel C a,b , Prunier AL a , Garry L c , Chau F b , Leclercq R a , Fantin B b . a Microbiologie, Centre Hospitalier Universitaire, Caen, France, b E9933, Faculté Médecine Xavier Bichat, France, c 0339, INSERM, Paris, France To get further insights into the role of the mutator phenotype in the osteomyelitis physio-pathology due to Staphylococcus aureus and also in antibiotic resistance, we studied the behaviour of two strains of S. aureusonly differing by their mutation rate in a rat model of bacterial osteomyelitis of the tibia. Strains of S. aureus RN4220 and its mutator counterpart inactivated in the mutL gene by the insertion of a suicide plasmid were used. Mutation frequency determined on rifampicin containing medium was 45 times higher with the mutator strain. The behaviour of the two strains was studied separately in vitro and in rat model of osteomyelitis. Competition studies were performed in 50 rats co-infected with the two strains at a same ratio. Ten rats were sacrificed at five different times from 3 days to sixth weeks post-inoculation. A similar experiment was performed after a first in vivo passage for one derivate of each strain. To study the effect of the mutator phenotype in the emergence of antibiotic resistance, 20 rats were infected by each strain separately and treated with rifampicin sc 20 mg/kg bid for 5 days. Animals were sacrificed 48 h after the last antibiotic injection. No difference was observed between the separate growth of the two strains in vitro and in vivo indicating no fitness defect in the mutator strain. In contrast, competitive studies indicated that the mutator strain was clearly disadvantaged since it was found in all rats and all study times at lower bacterial titers (range 4.6 log cfu/bone versus 3 log cfu/bone, P < 0.05). In addition, this competitive loss of the mutator strain was amplified after a second passage in vivo, with a 100-fold difference in cfu counts between the two strains (P < 0.05). In animals treated with rifampicin, resistant mutant appeared in one from eight animals infected with the mutator strain, while no rifampicin resistant mutant was detected in rats infected with the wild strain. We concluded that, in a model of chronic bone infection due to S. aureus, the mutator phenotype was associated with a decreased fitness. However, under antibiotic selective pressure, this initial disadvantage could be compensated by the increased rate of emergence of antibiotic resistant mutant and may lead to competitive advantage.

body_text.text: Outbreak of glycopepetid-resistant Enterococcus faecium in a French terciary care hospital: the end of the "French paradox"? Robin F d,e Introduction: Glycopeptid-resistant Enterococcus faecium (GREF) is one of the major cause of nosocomial infection in the USA but is still rare in Europe. We report the first outbreak of GREF which occurred in a hospital in Clermont-Ferrand, France.

Methods: A case-control study was performed in the Infectious Diseases and Haematology department. Cases were inpatients for whom GREF was isolated in faeces or other clinical cultures between the 1st of January and the 31 of July 2004. The control group was a randomized sample of inpatients during the same period and who did not acquire GREF. Each case was matched to three controls from the same specialty (infectious diseases or haematology).

Results: Sixteen cases of GREF carriage were identified in the department. GREF was cultured from the stools of all patients and, in addition, from urine in three and ascitis in one. The 6 month-cumulative incidence was 2.9% for that period compared to 0.4% during the same time in 2003 (p = 0.002). During the study period, GREF was isolated from 11 other inpatients from three other wards: abdominal surgery (four), gastroenterology (four), intensive care unit (three). Of these, GREF was cultured from urine in two, from Redivac ® discharge in three, from ascitis in one and from blood in three. Two patients with a GREF bacteraemia died as a direct consequence of the infection. Two strains were responsible for most of the colonizations. In multivariate analysis, controlling for time at risk and the Charlson Index of Comorbidity, the following variables found to be independently predictive for GREF carriage were prior exposure to third generation cephalosporin (OR = 10; 95% CI: 1.5-64; p = 0.02), antimicrobials regimen containing a beta lactamase inhibitor (OR = 5; 95% CI: 0.9-28; p = 0.07) and a urinary catheter in place during the period at risk (OR = 20; 95% CI: 1.3-291; p = 0.03).

Conclusion: This outbreak is likely to result from both multiantimicrobial pressure and patient to patient transmission. Isolation of the patients and enhancement of hygiene procedures have been implemented. This report might annunciate the end of what one could have called a "French (or a European) paradox" meaning a low rate of hospital colonization despite high antibiotic consumption and community reservoir of GREF.

Evaluation of a strategy of multiple-site screening of methicillinresistant Staphylococcus aureus at admission to a teaching hospital Eveillard M, Lancien E, Joly-guillou ML. Microbiologie-hygiène, CHU Louis Mourier, Colombes, France Objective: The carriage of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) is no longer confined to patients with known risk factors or to healthcare associated settings. To make up for performing screening cultures in an increasing amount of admitted patients, limiting the number of sampled sites could be an interesting alternative. Our objective was to determine the sensitivity of nasal cultures alone compared with the multiple-site screening undertaken in our hospital.

Methods: The study was performed during one year (2002) in a 600bed teaching hospital. For each MRSA carrier identified by multiple-site screening sample (nasal, axilla, rectal) on admission, MRSA-positive site combinations were recorded as follows: nasal alone (N), axilla alone (A), rectal alone (R), N + A, N + R, A + R, N + A, N + A + R. Concurrently, the cumulated number of days of hospitalisation, representing the number of theoretical isolation days (TID), was noted for MRSA carriers identified by screening. For the analysis, carriers were differentiated in nasal carriers (N or N + A or N + R or N + A + R) and other carriers (A, R, A + R). Intact skin and rectal carriers were identified by the same way.

Results: During the study, 123 MRSA carriers accounting for 1854 TID were identified among 1250 patients who underwent a multiple-site screening on admission. With nasal screening alone, 25.2% of MRSA carriers accounting for 530 TID (28.6%) would have been missed. Without rectal screening, 17.1% of carriers accounting for 431 TID (23.2%) would have been missed. Without axilla screening, only 8.1% of carriers accounting for 99 TID (5.4%) would have been missed. The proportion of carriers who would have not been identified with nasal screening alone was nearly twice higher among males than among females (36.5% versus 19.7%; P < 0.04).

Conclusion: Giving-up axilla cultures in non-ICU wards and carrying on rectal cultures would allow to screen 290 additional patients without extra-cost and should enable an higher sensitivity of the screening policy. Indeed, in the additional sampled population, a prevalence of MRSA carriage of 3.4% (10/290) would be sufficient to identify the number of carriers missed without axilla cultures.

The Antibiotic Study Group, Bichat Claude Bernard hospital-Paris VII University, Paris, France Background and objectives: There are few data on antimicrobial prescribing in the ER. The objectives of this study were to describe antimicrobial prescribing and timing and patterns of modifications in the subset of patients admitted to the hospital.
body_text.section: Antibiotic prescribing for adults hospitalized patients referred from the emergency room (ER)

body_text.text: Methods: Prospective study of patients who attended the ER during a 1-month period (November 2003) and who were prescribed antibiotic treatment (AT). ER and ward records information were used to complete a standardized case-report. The characteristics of AT were analysed at admission, on days 1, 3, 10 and at hospital discharge.
body_text.section: Antibiotic prescribing for adults hospitalized patients referred from the emergency room (ER)

body_text.text: Results: A total of 5714 adults attended the ER, of whom 234 (4%) were prescribed AT. Of these 234 patients, 100 (43%) were discharged home (median age: 34 years), 39 (17%) were referred to another hospital, and 95 (40%) were admitted to the same hospital (median age: 71 years). The most common suspected diagnoses leading to an AT were respiratory tract infections (n = 62, including 51 pneumonias) and urinary tract infections (UTI) (n = 19). Patients with pneumonia received more frequently a third generation cephalosporin (3GC) or amoxycillin-clavulanate alone or associated with fluoroquinolones (FQ) (40/51, 79%) than amoxicillin alone or associated with a macrolide (6/51, 12%). UTI were treated with FQ (n = 7) or 3GC alone (n = 3) or associated with aminoglycosides (n = 5). During hospital stay, the mean modifications of AT were: day 1 (n = 33), days 1-3 (n = 46) and days 3-10 (n = 24): broadening (34%, 13% and 8%) or narrowing (27%, 15% and 8%) of antimicrobial spectrum and oral switch (18%, 41% and 54%), respectively. For 13/95 patients (14%), AT was stopped within a median delay of 4 days because there was no evidence of bacterial infection. Prescribing was considered inappropriate in 33% of the 27 patients with documented infection. The median duration of AT was 13 days and 16.5 days for pneumonia and UTI, respectively.
body_text.section: Antibiotic prescribing for adults hospitalized patients referred from the emergency room (ER)

body_text.text: Conclusions: Antibiotic treatment is prescribed in 4% of all patients visiting a large teaching hospital. Most hospitalised patients are elderly patients with non-documented pneumonia who are usually treated with a long-course of broad-spectrum antibiotics. It is necessary to investigate the adequacy of these regimens to improve the targeted use of antibiotics.

body_text.text: A nosocomial outbreak of Acinetobacter baumannii isolates expressing the carbapenem-hydrolyzing oxacillinase oxa-58

Héritier C a , Dubouix A b , Poirel L a , Marty N b , Nordmann P a . a Hôpital de Bicêtre, Assistance Publique/Hôpitaux de Paris, Service de Bactériologie-Virologie, Le Kremlin-Bicetre, France, b CHU Rangueil, Laboratoire de Bactériologie-Hygiène, Toulouse, France

Recently, we have characterized a carbapenem-hydrolyzing oxacillinase, OXA-58, that is a representant of a novel group of oxacillinases, from an A. baumanniiclinical isolate isolated in the burns unit at the Rangueil Hospital in Toulouse in 2003. OXA-58 was weakly related to other oxacillinases sharing 33%, 47% and 48% amino acid identity with OXA-10, OXA-24 and OXA-23, respectively. The aim of this study was to analyze the spread of this oxacillinase gene as source of carbapenem-resistance in A. baumannii in that hospital. From August 2003 to March 2004, seven carbapenem-resistant A. baumannii isolates were collected. Six were from six patients from the burns unit and one was an environmental isolate, collected in the surgery block during systematic air sampling. PCR experiments using primers specific for the bla OXA-58 gene gave positive results for the seven carbapenem-resistant A. baumannii isolates. These carbapenem-resistant A. baumannii isolates had the same bla OXA-58 -positive plasmid of ca. 30 kb after plasmid extraction and hybridization with the bla OXA-58 probe. Genotypic comparison was performed for evaluating clonality of the isolates. Pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) was realized after digestion of whole-cell DNAs with ApaI restriction enzymes. PFGE analysis showed that the six carbapenem-resistant isolates from patients corresponded likely to a single clone, whereas the isolate from the environment, that was also bla OXA-58 positive, was of a different genotype. Identification of the same bla OXA-58 -positive plasmid in two different clones of A. baumannii indicated the spread of this plasmid. This study constitutes the second description of an outbreak of carbapenem-resistant A. baumannii producing a plasmid-encoded carbapenem-hydrolyzing oxacillinase, after that of OXA-23-producing A. baumanniistrains in Brazil. As observed for the other carbapenem-hydrolyzing oxacillinase genes, bla OXA-58 was not present in the form of a gene cassette in a class 1 integron, but associated with insertion sequences. Thus, spread of a novel ␤-lactamase-mediated resistance mechanism was identified, underlying emergence of novel carbapenem-hydrolyzing enzymes in A. baumannii.

Fillaux J a , Dubouix A a , Daude S a , Archambaud M a , Segonds C a , Conil C c , Laguerre J b , Marty N a . a Bactériologie-Hygiène, France, b Brulés, France, c Réanimation, CHU RANGUEIL, Toulouse, France Introduction: Acinetobacter baumannii is essentially a skin commensal which can turn into an opportunistic pathogen responsible for real outbreaks, particularly in intensive care units. In the recent past, multi-resistant A. baumannii strains have been described. During 2003 summer, an A. baumanni outbreak resulting in colonisation and infection was observed in our hospital. Amongst the isolated strains, none displayed the "national epidemic" clone producing the VEB-1 extended spectrum betalactamase (ESBL). The multiresistant strains we observed had thus two characteristic antibiotypes: in the intensive care unit, strains were exclusively susceptible to imipenem, tobramycin and amikacin while in the Burn unit, strains were only susceptible to amikacin.
body_text.section: Retrospective analysis of multi-resistant Acinetobacter baumannii strains isolated in a university hospital

body_text.text: Objectives: The aim of this work was to investigate whether the multiresistant strains had been already present in our hospital previously to the 2003 outbreak.
body_text.section: Retrospective analysis of multi-resistant Acinetobacter baumannii strains isolated in a university hospital

body_text.text: Methods: We listed all the clinical samples that had been positive for A. baumannii between 1 January 2000 and 31 December 2003. The multiresistant strains were then submitted to pulse-field gel electrophoresis after digestion by Sma I and Apa I enzymes and clinical characteristics were noted. Statistical analysis was performed using chi squrae test and Fischer's exact test.
body_text.section: Retrospective analysis of multi-resistant Acinetobacter baumannii strains isolated in a university hospital

body_text.text: Results: Amongst the 793 clinical isolates found, 149 (18.8%) corresponded to the following multi-resistance criteria: (1) susceptibility to imipenem, tobramycin and amikacin, (2) exclusive susceptibility to amikacin, (3) exclusive susceptibility to imipenem, (4) resistant to all antibiotics tested. The resistant strains were more likely isolated in the intensive care unit (60%). However, clinical samples were from various origins: non protected respiratory samples (43%) as well as blood cultures (5%). Simultaneous analysis of pulsotypes and antibiotypes was able to highlight that the outbreak observed in the intensive care unit could be linked to an initially endemic clone that had been isolated from 2001 and was responsible for the four previously mentioned antibiotypes. In the same manner, a second clone responsible for an ESBL phenotype was sporadically present in our institution. However, the strains isolated in the Burn unit were also genetically related one to each other, but the specific clone responsible appeared only in 2003.
body_text.section: Retrospective analysis of multi-resistant Acinetobacter baumannii strains isolated in a university hospital

body_text.text: Conclusion: This study allowed us to put in evidence the existence that several multi-resistant clones can endemically co-exist during several years and can only be detected thanks to acute survey of epidemic sources.
body_text.section: Retrospective analysis of multi-resistant Acinetobacter baumannii strains isolated in a university hospital

body_text.section: Investigation of the new QNR-based mechanism of quinolone resistance and first description in Enterobacter cloacae

body_text.text: Plasmid-mediated resistance to quinolones was recently described in Klebsiella pneumoniae and Escherichia coli and is due to the QNR protein that protects DNA gyrase from quinolone inhibition. Prevalence of qnr is between 2% and 11%, referring first studies in China, Spain and USA, and is unknown in France. The strains harbouring qnr gene are usually producing plasmid-mediated AmpC-type-␤-lactamase (PCase) or extended spectrum ␤-lactamase (ESBL). We have screened 478 nalidixic acid (Nal) resistant enterobacterial strains isolated in Henri Mondor hospital between 2002 and 2004 (316 Escherichia coli,100 Klebsiella pneumoniae, 28 Enterobacter spp., 20 Citrobacter freundii, 9Serratia marcescens, 3 Proteus and 2 Providencia) for the presence of qnr gene by PCR using specific primers amplifying an intragenic 543 bp fragment. Among them, 58 had a phenotype in concordance with a ESBL and three with a PCase. Nal-S strains (n = 20) were tested as negative controls. Positive control was the original strain K. pneumoniae UAB1. Each strain for which the PCR was positive was tested with two other couples of primers generating a 627 or a 661 bp intragenic fragment of qnr. PCR products when obtained were sequenced. Among the 478 strains, 441 were PCR negative, 33 were PCR positive with the first couple of primers, three of them were PCR positive with two couples of primers, and only one strain was positive with the three couples of primers. For all the strains except the latter one, PCR products did not have the expected size and sequences were different from qnr. For the only strain that was positive with the three couples of primers, the sequence of the PCR products was identical to qnr excepted one base, resulting in a silent mutation. This strain was an Enterobacter cloacae with a high level of resistance to ciprofloxacin and had a ESBL phenotype. We described the first strain ofEnterobacter cloacae that harbours the qnr gene known to mediate plasmid-borne quinolone resistance. This was the only strain among 478 enterobacterial strains tested, resulting in a prevalence of 0.2% in this serie. Large scale survey among hospitals with investigation of all the enterobacterial species will be necessary to confirm this low prevalence rate of qnr in France.
body_text.section: Investigation of the new QNR-based mechanism of quinolone resistance and first description in Enterobacter cloacae

body_text.text: Mammeri H a , Van De Loo M a , Poirel L a , Martinez-martinez L b , Nordmann P a . a Service de Bactériologie-Virologie, Hôpital de Bicêtre, Le Kremlin-Bicêtre, France, b Department of Microbiology, University Hospital Marquès de Valdecilla, Santander, Spain Objectives: Although quinolone resistance results mostly from chromosomal mutations, recent surveys indicated that such resistance may be mediated by a plasmid-encoded qnr gene in Enterobacteriaceae. Thus, 297 nalidixic-acid resistant Escherichia coli clinical isolates (out of a total of 2700 E. coli isolates) that had been isolated at the Bicêtre hospital (France) were screened for qnr by PCR.
body_text.section: Emergence of plasmid-mediated quinolone resistance in Escherichia coli in Europe

body_text.text: Results: A single E. coli isolate was identified that carried a ca. 180 kb conjugative plasmid pQR1 harboring a qnr determinant. It conferred lowlevel resistance to quinolones and was associated with a chromosomal mutation in the subunit A of the topoisomerase II gene. The qnr gene was located on a sul1-type class 1 integron just downstream of a CR1 element comprising the Orf513 recombinase. Promoter sequences for qnr expression overlapped the extremity of CR1, thus indicating the role of CR1 in expression of antibiotic resistance genes. This sul1-type integron was different from other qnr-positive sul1-type integrons identified in American and Chinese enterobacterial isolates. In addition, plasmid pQR1 carried another class 1 integron that was identical to In53 from E. coli. In53 possessed a series of gene cassettes including those coding for the extended-spectrum ␤lactamase VEB-1, the rifampin ADP ribosyltransferase ARR-2, and several aminoglycoside resistance markers.
body_text.section: Emergence of plasmid-mediated quinolone resistance in Escherichia coli in Europe

body_text.text: Conclusion: This is the first report of plasmid-mediated quinolone resistance in Europe that was associated with an unknown level of plasmid-mediated multiresistance in Enterobacteriaceae.
body_text.section: Emergence of plasmid-mediated quinolone resistance in Escherichia coli in Europe

body_text.text: Type II topoisomerase genotype of quinolone-resistant clinical isolates of Escherichia coli isolated in France Lascols C a , Attalah L a , Soussy CJ a , Cambau E a,b . a Bactériologie-Virologie-Hygiène, CHU Henri Mondor APHP, Créteil, France, b Bactériologie-Hygiène, CHU Pitié Salpêtrière APHP, Université De Paris, France

The aim of the study was to seek for mutations of the DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV genes involved in quinolone resistance in clinical strains of Escherichia coli isolated from multicenter studies. The strains studied were 74 clinical isolates including 33 nalidixic acid (Nal)-resistant (R) and ciprofloxacin (Cip) R, one NalR Cip-intermediate (I), 40 NalR Cipsusceptible (S). Mutations in the quinolone-resistance-determining region (QRDR) of the four topoisomerase genes (gyrA, gyrB, parC and parE) were assessed by PCR sequencing.

Mutations known to be associated with quinolone resistance were shown in all the strains but one. gyrA mutations were Ser83Leu (n = 68) or Ser83Ala (n = 2), Asp87Asn (n = 31), Asp87Tyr (n = 4) or Asp87Gly (n = 3); parC mutations were Ser80Ile (n = 28) or Ser80Arg (n = 5), Glu84Lys (n = 7) or Glu84Gly (n = 1). parE mutation (Leu445His) was found in two isolates whereas no isolate harboured mutations usually described in gyrB. Among the 34 NalR CipR strains (geometric mean MIC [MICg] Cip = 19.3 mg/L), 31 strains (91.2%) had three QRDR mutations (two gyrA + one parC) (MICg Cip = 19.6 mg/L), one strain had four mutations (two gyrA + one parC + one parE) (MIC Cip = 16 mg/L), and one strain had two mutations (one gyrA + one parC) (MIC Cip = 16 mg/L). Among the 40 NalR CipS strains (MICg Cip = 0.19 mg/L), 31 strains (77.5%) (MICg Cip = 0.15 mg/L) had one mutation in gyrA, six strains (MICg Cip = 0.6 mg/L) had two mutations (one gyrA + one parC) and two strains (MICg Cip = 0.25 mg/L) had three mutations (two gyrA + one parC). No mutation in the QRDRs was observed for only one strain (MIC Cip = 0.25 mg/L). Unknown mutations were also observed ingyrB (Ser492Asn for nine NalR CipR and three NalR CipS strains), in parC (Ser57Thr for two NalR CipR and one NalR CipS strains) and in parE (Leu416Phe for three NalR CipR strains). This study showed that NalR clinical isolates of E. coli, either CipS or CipR, harboured at least one mutation in the topoisomerase genes (gyrA, gyrB, parC and parE) and that NalR CipR isolates harboured the association of mutations in two or three of these genes. Whereas we did not find any gyrB mutant, we described the first clinical isolate harbouring the parE mutation Leu445His. Unknown mutations observed in gyrB, parC and parE should be investigated for their involvement in quinolone resistance. Travellers in tropical countries import in France more than 5000 P. falciparum (Pf) isolates annually from which 10-15% are sent to us for typing. Isolates from symptomatic patients without previous drug intake (HPLC measurement) are selected for drug susceptibility testing with in vitro tests (1993-2004, n = 1100) and with molecular markers (1996-2004, n = 2900) . Characteristics of corresponding patients are similar over the years, including: African natives (71%); living in France (86%); travelling in Africa (98,9%); returning either from Cameroon, Cote d'Ivoire, Senegal, Mali or Comoros (68%); mean age (32 years); children under 15 years of age (14%); and sex ratio (M:F = 1.78). Among these, prevalence of Pf chloroquine resistance (in vitro IC 50 > 100 nM) is 0.41 in 1993-2002, and 0.55 in 2003-2004 ; prevalence of Pf cycloguanil resistance (in vitro IC 50 > 500 nM or DHFR mutation S108N) is 0.28 in 1993-1996, 0.51 in 1997-2002, and 0.62 in 2003-2004 . Foot-step increase of Pf resistance was observed for the two antimalarials. These results are used on an annual basis to adjust prophylactic recommendations for travellers to each endemic country (invs.sante.fr/beh/). Following WHO guidelines for use of antimalarials, we consider now a prevalence of 0.25 of resistance to chloroquine plus cycloguanil in Pf from an endemic country as the upper limit for recommending prophylactic use of the association (countries with Pf resistance of group 2): Togo and Benin exceeded this limit in 1996 -1997 and Senegal in 2003 -2004 . Prevalence of Pf resistance to mefloquine, atovaquone-proguanil or doxycycline is still under 0.25 in all endemic countries and are recommended for prophylaxis in countries with chloroquine plus cycloguanil Pf resistance >0.25 (countries of group three). Indirect evidence for efficiency of these recommendations is gained from the figure of 15 travellers among 728 Pf attack analysed by CNRCP in 2003 having correctly followed them (2%). Since the 1999 French consensus, chloroquine or sulphadoxine-pyrimethamine are no longer used for Pf treatment. Quinine resistance has only been detected in this period in few Pf isolates from Asia and no chloroquine failure was suspected in imported Plasmodium vivax, ovale or malariae.

body_text.section: Atovaquone-proguanil therapeutic failures in France in 2003-2004

body_text.text: In 1999, marketing of atovaquone-proguanil (Malarone ® ) expanded the very limited range of antimalarial drugs with low falciparum resistance. The combination is indicated for malaria prophylaxis in areas with chloroquine resistance and for treatment of uncomplicated P. falciparum malaria. Since 2002, both indications gained increased favour of French physicians and travellers, owing to it is good tolerance. From the beginning of prescription in Europe and North America, six therapeutic failures were published yet, one early therapeutic failure (ETF) and five late one (LTF). In three cases, failure was confirmed by blood drug dosage. A unique mutated codon (268) on the parasite target of atovaquone, cytochrome b, was present in 4/6. Association between therapeutic failure and cytochrome b mutation needs further confirmation. This last two years, we were informed of 251 atovaquone-proguanil treatments in travellers contamined mostly in West Africa and Comoros. From 148 cases with clinical follow up files, five failures were recorded, three ETF and two LTF. Isolates were analysed by dosing d 3 residual drugs in plasma, measuring in vitro atovaquone susceptibility and sequencing d 0 and d fail cytochrome b gene. In two cases, bad observance and/or poor absorption is the likely failure explanation. Two out of three isolates from true therapeutic failure presented with a single mutation causing amino acid change, respectively: M116I and Y268S. This compare to a series of 85 isolates, without known failures, in which only one mutation (codon 314) was identified. These results confirm high conservation of the Plasmodium cytochrome b house keeping gene. Three other failure cases require more analysis to conclude. In spite of fast resistance emergence when atovaquone was used alone, its combination with proguanil exhibited satisfactory efficacy, tolerance and safety. Drug resistance associated with mutations on the cytochrome b gene leading to therapeutic failures of P. falciparum are yet rarely encountered with atovaquone-proguanil.
body_text.section: Atovaquone-proguanil therapeutic failures in France in 2003-2004

body_text.text: Illnesses in travellers returning from the tropics: a prospective study of 622 patients Objectives: Each year about 50 million people travel from industrialised countries to developing countries. Although between 8% and 19% of travellers consult a doctor after returning from the tropics, the full spectrum of health complaints is unknown.

Methods:We analysed the relative frequency of travel-associated health complaints in all travellers (immigrants, expatriates, business travellers and tourists) consulting our department between November 2002 and May 2003.

Results: A total of 622 patients were studied [256 women, 366 men; median age 38 years; 282 tourists (45.3%), 210 immigrants (33.8%), 88 expatriates (14.1%), 42 business travellers (6.7%)]. The median duration of travel was 36.9 days. The main destinations were Africa (57.6%) and Asia (26.4%). A total of 637 diseases were diagnosed, distributed as follows: skin diseases (23.4%), gastrointestinal infections (19.1%), respiratory tract infections (11.5%), malaria (8.8%), viral hepatitis (4.1%), urinary tract infections (3.4%), sexually transmitted infections (3.4%), dengue fever (2.5%), tuberculosis (2.7%), and others (13.8%). 257 travellers consulted for fever. Malaria and intestinal tract infections accounted for 21% and 23% of diagnoses in these patients, respectively. Malaria was associated with travel in Africa (p = 0.001) and immigrant status (p < 10-4), while respiratory and urinary tract infections were associated with tourist status (p < 10-4 and =0.02 respectively) and dengue fever with travel in Asia (p = 10-3). Overall, 230 diagnoses (36.1%) corresponded to imported tropical diseases, the main imported diseases being malaria, schistosomiasis, amebiasis, gastrointestinal disorders caused by intestinal nematodes, and dengue fever.

Conclusions. Tropical diseases are not the leading cause of consultation in travellers returning from the tropics. With the noteworthy exception of dengue fever and invasive schistosomiasis, immigrants visiting their home countries are the travellers most at risk of common tropical diseases.

A post-marketing study (PMS) to confirm the cardiac safety profile of IZILOX ® Veyssier P b , Voiriot P c , Bégaud B a , Brentano CF d , a Unité de Pharmaco-Epidémiologie, Université Victor Segalen, Bordeaux, France, b Service de Médecine Interne, Centre Hospitalier, Compiègne, France, c Unité de Pharmaco-Epidémiologie, Vandoeuvre Les Nancy, Nancy, France, d Service de Pharmacologie Clinique, Hôpital Saint Antoine, Paris, France Background: As mentioned in the Summary of Product Characteristics (SPC), ECG analysis done in clinical trials showed that PO moxifloxacin (Izilox ® ) resulted in QT prolongation in some subjects (mean: 6 ms ± 26, 1.4% relative to initial value). To confirm the Izilox ® cardiac safety profile, we carried out a PMS study.

Methods: Prospective observational study in infected adults treated with Izilox ® in usual medical practice. The subject observation period included the treatment duration with Izilox ® + a 3-day follow-up after end of therapy (EOT). To assess the Izilox ® cardiac safety profile, type and incidence of critical adverse events (AE) were analyzed by an independent Expert Committee (EC). These events were defined as any clinical event potentially surrogate of ventricular rhythm disorder consequent to QT prolongation. They were assessed as events of documented cardiac origin (confirmed by additional exams/ECG), not documented cardiac origin (strong clinical presumption but no additional exam/ ECG) or extra-cardiac origin. After the initial visit, all subjects (subj.) were followed for any AE occurrence up to 3 days after EOT.

Results: Of 13,578 ITT subjects (mean age 51 ± 17, females 49%) 54%, 37% and 8% were treated for acute sinusitis, acute exacerbation of chronic bronchitis and community acquired pneumonia respectively. A total of 1046 AE (678 subj., 5%), mainly gastro-intestinal disorders, was reported. 854 AE (564 subj., 4.15%) were assessed as drug-related. Of the 1046 AE, 189 were considered to be critical events (159 subj., 1.2%) by the EC. An extra cardiac origin was assessed for 154 AE, a documented cardiac origin was assessed for 1 AE (not drug-related), and a not documented cardiac origin was assessed for 34 AE (28 subj., 0.21%). Of those 34 AE, 25 (19 subj., 0.14%) were considered drug-related: palpitations (n = 13) tachycardia (n = 4) malaise (n = 4) vertigo (n = 3) pallor (n = 1). Nineteen (13 subj., 0.10%) of these 25 AE led to Izilox ® discontinuation; all the 25 AE resolved.

Conclusions: This PMS study indicates that Izilox ® clinical safety profile was similar to that previously known with no unexpected adverse effects identified and was consistent with the current SPC. No clinically severe drug-related adverse event of cardiac origin was observed. Methods: The consumption of antibacterials using ATC/DDD classification (WHO version 2004) was expressed in DDD/1000 inhabitants per day (DID). We re-alised that targeting a few key intravenous broad spectrum antibiotics-viz. meropenem, ceftazidime, ciprofloxacine, amikacin, piperacillin, vancomycin and teicoplanin-would produce significant impact on clinical prescription and cost without resulting in excessive workload. Introduction: Antimicrobial disk diffusion susceptibility testing is devoted in a clinical context to predict whether an antibiotic regimen will be effective. Test performance should be evaluated through predictive values of a report, i.e. the test ability to predict true-S, true-I, true-R isolates. This approach implies that variation of susceptibility prevalence (frequency of susceptible, intermediate and resistant isolates) affects the predictive value of a result, simply because the level of discrepancies will vary with the prevalence of S, I, R categories. The prevalence effect is traditionally taken into account through positive and negative predictive values, but has never been evaluated with three-class result tests such as agar diffusion based susceptibility testing.

Aim: This study presents two simulated examples (co-amoxiclav and lomefloxacin) to illustrate the impact the susceptibility prevalence variation may have on the performance of the disk diffusion method.

Methods: We developed tools for evaluating quality prediction of a result and we quantified the influence of the susceptibility prevalence variation on the disk diffusion method performance through a modelling approach. For each antimicrobial agent, simulations based on a resampling procedure were performed from minimum inhibitory concentration/diameter experimental datasets. Experimental variability on minimum inhibitory concentration and diameters was taken into account in the simulations.

Results: The results show that prevalence impacts on the disk diffusion method performance and may be quantitatively noteworthy for some antimicrobial agents considering the prevalence variations recorded with time, location and type of species.

Conclusions: Consequences of these results on zone diameter breakpoint determination policy are raised. This implies the following should be considered (i) take into account more rigorously the susceptibility prevalence in studies dealing with zone diameter breakpoint determination and performance evaluation, (ii) re-evaluate disk diffusion breakpoint consistency when the weight of prevalence variation is noteworthy, (iii) estimate consequences of a breakpoint international consensus on prediction quality and appropriate patient management.

Results Human metapneumovirus is a recently discovered virus that causes respiratory disease in children and in adults. hMPV infection has clinical characteristics similar to those of respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection, ranging from mild upper respiratory tract infection to bronchiolitis and pneumonia. HMPV is genetically related to avian pneumovirus C but does not replicate in turkeys or chickens. It has been shown to replicate in primates and small animals such as guinea pigs, mice and Syrian golden hamsters. This study was undertaken to evaluate the suitability of BALB/c mice as models for hMPV infection. hMPV is not a natural pathogen of mice. However, we showed that intranasal inoculation of BALB/c mice with hMPV led to a productive infection with significant morbidity. Indeed, hMPV induced overt clinical disease in mice, with a significant weight loss on day 2. Lung viral replication occurred from days 3 to 5. hMPV elicited high levels of IgG-specific antibody response in sera with a strong increase in both IgG1 and IgG2a levels suggesting that hMPV induced a systemic Th1/Th2-like response. This mixed Th1/Th2-like profile is in accordance with the fact that both IFN-gamma (Th1) and IL-4 (Th2) were produced in bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL). Acute infection with hMPV elicited a rapid and sustained pulmonary inflammatory response without eosinophilia. Airway obstruction measured by plethysmography, and airway hyperresponsiveness after metacholine challenge were significantly increased in hMPV-infected mice compared to controls. In summary, we present an animal model that enables the investigation of immunodeterminants of protection and recovery from hMPV infection.

HHV-6 as a causative agent of fulminant hepatic failure in young children Among young children, a rising number of cases of fulminant hepatic failures (FHF) remains of undetermined cause. Human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6), a betaherpesvirus, is able to infect hepatocytes in vitro, and has been associated with FHF and acute liver injury. The aim of this study was to evaluate the incidence of HHV-6 infection in a group of pediatric patients harbouring various acute liver diseases, in comparison with a control group of children with stable chronic liver diseases. Twenty-three children (median age: 24 months; range: 7-61) with different types of liver injuries underwent liver transplantation: 6 FHF with undetermined cause, three FHF with an etiologic cause (hepatitis A virus (HAV) infection, Wilson disease, autoimmune hepatitis), three acute decompensations of chronic liver diseases (ADCLD), and 11 stable chronic liver diseases (biliary cirrhosis). HHV-6 DNA was detected and quantified in explanted livers and peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) at the time of tranplantation. Among children with FHF of undetermined cause and ADCLD, HHV-6 DNA was detected in 100% of liver specimens and 50% of PBMC specimens, with HHV-6 median load higher in liver biopsies (1070 copies/10 6 cells) than in PBMCs (29 copies/10 6 cells). These results are in favour of viral replication in hepatic tissue. Conversely, among children with stable chronic liver diseases, only one had HHV-6 positive detection in liver and PBMCs, with low HHV-6 loads (26 and 323 copies/10 6 cells, respectively). HHV-6 was not detected in the patient with HAV hepatitis, and HHV-6 loads were quite low in both liver biopsy and PBMCs (125 and 168 copies/10 6 cells, respectively) from the one with Wilson disease. Of note, HHV-6 loads were high for the patient with autoimuune hepatitis (13,768 and 10,000 copies/10 6 cells, in liver and PBMCs, respectively). All the HHV-6 identified were variant B. In Germany a mandatory health check, which usually takes place at the age of six, before enrolment in primary school is performed by the Public Children and Youth Health Service Centre (PCYHS). At this visit the parents receive additional information about vaccines, which their children had not yet obtained. In order to increase vaccination rates a vaccination register in the city of Essen/Germany was established. At the first check of vaccination cards of 6th graders (n = 4 568) only 15% of the students had the complete vaccination set they needed at their age.
