According to official statistics of the Infectious Diseases Hospital now we have change of etiology of the purulent meningitis among adults in the Republic of Belarus. The most common agent is Str. pneumonia, causing approximately 50% the purulent meningitis. N. meningitis causes approximately 25% the bacterial meningitis. L. monocytogenes is a very common agent of meningitis in patients over 55 years, who have some chronic diseases, for example diabetic or alcoholism. As a rule, the drug users have the bacterial meningitis, caused by S. aureus. In these cases the meningitis is the first manifestation of the bacterial endocarditis. Rare cases of bacterial meningitis caused by H. influenzae have the particular interest. Nowadays taking into consideration the considerable increase of resistance of Str. pneumoniae to penicillin in countries of Eastern Europe, we use cephalosporins of the third generation as the first line of therapy. The ideal antibiotics for these patients are ceftriaxone or high doses of cefotaxime. As a rule both the immunosuppressive patients and the old patients received the combination of ceftriaxone/cefotaxime plus ampicillin (16-24 g/day). The etiologic therapy of the bacterial meningitis, caused by S. aureus, includes cephalosporins of the third generation or meropenem. Meropenem is used by patients with neutropenia or other immunosuppressive states. We add vancomycin to the first line of therapy only when we suspect hospital-acquired meningitis. When we prescribe antibacterial therapy, we pay attention to the basic pathology, age of patients and initial localization of infection. Detection of HCV-RNA in blood serum is used for therapy monitoring of patients with hepatitis C. Despite of HCV-RNA elimination from blood serum during treatment in some patients HCV viremia appears again after completion of therapy. The aim of the study was to assess HCV-RNA in peripheral blood leukocytes of hepatitis C patients in relation to HCV-RNA and antibodies to HCV in the serum. The study involved 40 patients undergoing anti-viral therapy (interferon + ribavirin). RNA isolated from serum and peripheral blood leukocytes (by Qiagen kits for genomic or viral RNA) was examined for the presence of HCV-RNA by RT-PCR technique using specific oligonucleotide primers or by comercially available kits (Amplicor, ROCHE). In order to show possible presence of HCV sequence in peripheral blood leukocytes, molecular DNA probes was constructed with PCR amplicon and biotin labelled by nick translation. HCV sequences was detected by FISH and also on chromatin fibers by extended chromatin fibers in situ hybridization (ECFs-FISH). Twenty two patients out of 40 eliminated HCV-RNA from the serum and 18 remained HCV-positive. In the serum negative group HCV-RNA was detected in mononuclear cells of 10 patients. The presence of HCV-RNA in mononuclear cells was confirmed by FISH technique. In ECFs-FISH procedure no signal was found in all examined patients. Our data suggest that leukocytes infected with HCV can serve as virus reservuare. HCV-RNA serum negative patients after completion of anti-viral therapy having HCV-RNA in their leukocytes would be at greater risk of hepatitis C recurrence. These HCV-RNA serum negative but leukocyte positive patients would be a potential source of spreading HCV infection. This work was supported by KBN grant nr 3PO5E10124.

To evaluate this particular point in our local population, we analysed retrospectively 89 HPV-16 positive cervical samples obtained from 78 women consulting the gynaecological unit of Nantes university hospital. 20.3% of samples had a normal cytology, whereas the others showed a cervical intraneoplasia grade 1 (20.3%) or grades 2-3 (66.3%). 84 E6 genes and 88 E7 genes were successfully amplified by specific PCR. Variants were analysed by direct nucleotide sequencing and multiple sequence alignments of the full length E6 and E7 gene were performed with Mega program. Phylogenetic trees were constructed. No insertions or deletions in the sequenced fragments were observed. Only 31.3% of the HPV-16 E6/E7 genes were identical to the prototype sequence (T350). The previously described T350G mutation in E6 gene was present in 57.1% of HPV-16. A total of 15 (5 non-published, 10 non-synonymous) and 5 mutations (1 non-published and 2 non-synonymous) were identified in E6 and E7 gene, respectively. Four samples contained multiple nucleotide changes typical of non-European variants. No significant associations were observed between variants and the different cytological classes, but interestingly, the four multiple variant samples were all associated with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (3 high-grade, 1 low grade). Since the risk of high grade cervical neoplasia seems to increase in patients infected with certain HPV-16 variants, the knowledge of their local prevalence is of interest. Furthermore, the determination of E6/E7 variants may be useful in the perspective of HPV antiviral treatment and vaccine. Pleural empyema is a rare complication of bacterial pneumonia, associated with a severe morbidity. We recently observed an increase in the incidence of pneumococcal pleural empyema in children admitted at the Necker hospital. The diagnosis of pneumococcal empyema infection, based on the culture of blood or pleural fluid, is frequently negative due to previous administration of antibiotics. Rapid pneumococcal capsular antigen (PAC) detection by latex agglutination has been used for several years, but its diagnostic value is not clearly established. In this work, we evaluated retrospectively the accuracy of PAC in the diagnosis of S. pneumoniae empyema compared to culture in blood and pleural fluid and molecular biology in pleural fluid. We tested for PAC, 55 pleural empyema cases collected over a 4-year period (2000) (2001) (2002) (2003) , according to criteria of Light. Microbiological documentation of causal pathogen, by culture or PCR rRNA16S and sequencing, were found in 30 cases including 21 cases with S. pneumoniae. The other bacteria were S. aureus (4) and S. pyogenes (5), all found with a negative PAC in pleural fluid. Among the 21 pneumococcal empyema, PAC were positive in 18 cases providing a sensitivity of 84%. PAC were positive in seven cases, while bacterial cultures of pleural empyema were sterile. In five of these seven cases, the diagnosis of pneumococcal empyema was confirmed by PCR (4) when it was performed, or with positive culture of other clinical sample (1). In two cases, the positive PAC were not confirmed despite a positive microscopic examination in one case. The discrepancy between culture and PAC could be explained, according to clinical history of the patients, by previous administration of antibiotics. PAC detection in pleural fluid is a useful test in diagnosis strategy of pneumococcal empyema in children with a high predictive positive value (94%). The low predictive negative value (77%) does make it impossible to rule out the diagnosis of pneumococcal empyema. Therefore, the detection of PAC provides an additional and rapid response in children with pneumococcal empyema, including those having received previous antibiotic therapy.

The secretion in significant amounts of staphylococcal bicomponent leukotoxin LukE-LukD has been associated with antibiotic-associated diarrhoea (+enterotoxin A), and with bullous impetigo (+epidermolysins). Secretion of the toxin is observed for about 35% of routine isolates whereas the corresponding gene is present in more than 85% of these isolates. We analysed 19 independent isolates both for the presence of the LukE-LukD operon and for the toxin production, and tentatively developed a PCR test that detected a deleterious mutation in given isolates. Furthermore, gene expression was assessed by using a competitive RT-PCR test to verify the role of an inserted sequence in the promoter, and sequences corresponding to the secreted toxins were cloned and expressed in E. coli to assess their biological function compared to a control toxin. On the 19 isolates, only 16 (84%) carried the LukE-LukD operon and 8 (42%) secreted the leucotoxin. The operon sequence of four of the isolates revealed numerous mutations that may affect the protein structure, but the three expression-deficient strains showed the deletion of one basis just after the initiation codon. This deletion made impossible any functional translation, despite corresponding mRNAs were synthesized at levels comparable to the control. Four isolates were estimated to carry this deletion among the 19 studied. When proteins were expressed in E. coli some mutations were identified as able to inactivate the leucotoxin. Taken together, this study evidences the extreme variability of the LukE-LukD operon and the lack of toxin expression/function of the toxin for about half of the isolates even genes are present. This illustrates the discrepancy between gene presence that might be detected by genotyping tests and the effective production of a functional toxin. Thus, phenotyping methods remains indicated for the detection of such a leucotoxin to avoid false-positive data, and previous clinical associations remain significant.

body_text.section: Upregulation of protein a by the Panton Valentine leukocidin phage phiSLT in Staphylococcus aureus

body_text.text: Staphylococcal infections are frequent and represent a major public health issue. Although resistance to methicillin used to be an exclusivity restrained to hospitals for years, a worldwide emergence of communityacquired methicillin-resistant S. aureus(CAMRSA) clones has been noticed. The inter-human skin-to-skin transmission is the postulated cause of the rapid epidemic spreading of these clones. CAMRSA strains have three common characteristics: a type IV SCCmec cassette (staphylococcal cassette chromosome), a type 3 agrallele (accessory gene regulator) and a phage (phiSLT) carrying the Panton Valentine leukocidin (PVL) gene. The combination of these elements appears to provide to the strains a selective advantage with an increased epidemic potential. We hypothesized that the insertion of the phage phiSLT is a determinant of dysregulation in the staphylococcal proteome, by modulation of the expression of protein A, one of the major surface protein of S. aureus. We analysed the expression of protein A in eleven isogenic couples of S. aureus strains before and after transduction of the phiSLT phage. Each strain had been inactivated for a major regulation system of the virulence of S. aureus: two upregulating systems Rot and SarS, and three downregulating systems SarA, Agr and ArlRS. The expression of protein A was analysed by Northern and Western blots. We observed that the acquisition of phage phiSLT induced an overexpression of protein A in several isogenic strains, notably in rot and arl-insertion mutants. The up-regulation of protein A was more prominent at the protein level rather than at the transcriptional level. These results confirm that the presence of phiSLT not only brings a major cytolytic toxin (i.e. the PVL) but also induces an over-expression of protein A and potentially of other virulence factors, that may enhance the colonizing and/or invasing capacities of S. aureus. R&D, Pharmaceutica, Worcester, UK Evolution of bacterial cell walls that resist the action of beta-lactam antibiotics, continues to pose unique challenges to the treatment of infection. An emerging technology of 'bacterial transforming agents (BTA) identifies molecules that reverse cell wall resistance primarily to beta-lactams and related agents, by therapeutically targeting moieties involved in the binding of muropeptide tails to cell wall cross-links. Moieties that mimic those in the pentaglycine cross-links of S. aureus, including methicillin-sensitive (MSSA) and methicillin-resistant (MRSA) strains, can result in peptidoglycan muropeptides terminating with a d-Ala-X, instead of d-Ala-d-Ala. BTAs similarly interact with muropeptide tail-cross-links assemblies to hypersensitise the cell wall, transforming MRSA into MSSA, without eliminating PBP2. As a basic test of the technology in vitro, a glycine benzyl ester at 0.2% ww/v, reduced the MICs of 20 MRSA (including UK Epidemic MRSAs-1, 15, 16 and 17) from >256 mg/l to 2-4 mg/l. Other BTAs increase potency by 10-100 times, such that their co-formulation with betalactamase-resistant anti-staphylococcal beta-lactams or related antimicrobial for topical treatment becomes immediately possible. In addition, MICs of vancomycin for MRSA with reduced glycopeptide-sensitivity, were reduced from 4.0 to <0.5 mg/l. There is also some activity against vancomycinresistant Enterococcus faecium. None of these substances have antimicrobial activity in their own right and MRSA are only transformed into MSSA in the presence of a BTA. A specific agent with established pharmaco-kinetics and toxicity data, that reduces MICs of methicillin from >256 to >4.0 mg/l, in the presence of serum, is a 'bench-mark' coformulant with antimicrobials such as flucloxacillin and cloxacillin for in vivo study.

Sixty two strains were compared by spoligotyping according to Kamerbeek et al. Spoligotyping is a typing method based on DNA polymorphism present at one particular chromosomal locus, the "direct repeat" (DR), which is only present in M.tuberculosis complex bacteria. The number of DR elements in the cluster can vary between strains of the species. These 36 bp DRs are interspersed by non-repetitive DNA spacers of 36-41 bp. Forty three spacers representative of the M. tuberculosis complex strains are synthesized as oligonucleotides and immobilized on a nylon membrane. Isolates are strain-typed on the basis of detecting the presence, or the absence, of specific spacers using PCR and a reverse-line hybridization technique. body_text.section: Septic shock from Mycobacterium tuberculosis in a patient recently diagnosed with HIV infection

body_text.text: We present a 22-year-old patient from Ethiopia who admitted to our hospital because of high fever and malaise. The clinical examination reveals enlarged lymph nodes at her upperclavicular space and the axillaries, high body temperature and loss of weight. Her liver was palpable. Her medical record was unremarkable and she mentioned a healthy life before she gets sick. The laboratory values were consisted with anemia and hypoalbuminaemia. Abdominal ultrasound revealed enlarged lymph nodes. Excision of the lymph nodes in the upperclavicular space was performed and massive white material was produced and the microscopic examination showed Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection. Chest X-ray was consistent with miliary Tb. 48 h after her admission to the hospital the patient's condition was deteriorated; her blood pressure was decreased her pulse rate was 120/min and the temperature was 39 • C. The HIV antibody test turned to be positive and coinfection with M. tuberculosis was recognized. The patient was placed on anti HIV and anti-Tb therapy as well, but 36 h later she succumbs. This is fulminant Tb sepsis case in the setting of human immunodeficiency virus infection in a patient that was previously remained free of symptoms.

body_text.text: Methods: Seven and eleven clinical strains were found to overproduce MexAB-OprM or MexXY efflux systems, respectively, by immunoblot and qRT-PCR experiments. Gene sequencing revealed no mutation in the QR-DRs (gyrA, gyrB, parC and parE) of these isolates. MICs were determined by microbroth dilution assay and MBCs were assessed by the killing curve method. PK/PD parameters were calculated by using a Monte-Carlo simulation conducted with various FQ regimens on 1000 patients. We chose an AUC 0-24 /MIC ≥ 125 and a Cmax/MIC ≥ 10 as the pharmacodynamic targets predicting clinical outcome.

Results: Overexpression of MexAB-OprM or MexXY increased the MICs of all the FQs two-to eight-fold. For example, ciprofloxacin MICs reached 0.5-1 g/mL when the pumps were overexpressed. In addition, MBCs were two-to four-fold higher than the MICs for all the FQs tested. Monte-Carlo simulation showed that the PK/PD parameter attainment rates decreased dramatically as a result of efflux-mediated resistance. Success rates were as low as 4% even with simulation of aggressive treatment (IV ciprofloxacin 800 mg tid) when ciprofloxacin MIC reached 0.5 g/mL.

Conclusion: FQs exhibit decreased bacteriostatic activities but remain bactericidal on efflux-overexpressing mutants. The low resistance levels conferred by efflux mechanisms are however predicted to result in poor clinical outcomes. Overall, these data strongly suggest that while modest, active efflux provides P. aeruginosa with a resistance that may be sufficient to impair the efficacy of single therapy by FQs.

The objectives were to study the role of the multidrug efflux system AcrAB-TolC in resistance of multidrug-resistant Salmonella Typhimurium DT104 and DT204 strains to detergents and bile salts, and also to evaluate the role of the components AcrB and TolC in the colonisation of these strains in chicks. acrB and tolC mutant strains were constructed by insertional inactivation or deletion of the genes, respectively. MICs of detergent (SDS) and bile salts were determined for the wild-type strains, the acrB, and the tolC mutants. The effect of sodium choleate (CHOL) on the in vitro growth of these strains was also evaluated. The LD50 s of the strains were measured in a day old chicken model, inoculated with several doses (3-9 log 10 cfu) per os, at 7 days post-inoculation. The colonisation levels were assessed at the sublethal dose 7 days post-inoculation by determining the number of CFU of Salmonella in the faeces, caeca, spleen, and liver. In the case of the acrB mutants, the MIC values of SDS, sodium deoxycholate (DOC) and CHOL decreased 64-128-fold, 2-8-fold and not significantly, respectively, relative to those of the wild type strains. For the tolC mutants, MICs of SDS, DOC and CHOL decreased 1024-2048-fold, 512-fold, and 256-fold, respectively. Thus, the decrease in resistance levels to SDS and bile salts was much more important for the tolC than for the acrB mutants. CHOL did not affect the in vitro growth of the wild-type strains or the acrB mutants but inhibited that of the tolC mutants. The LD50s were 6 log 10 and 7 log 10 cfu for one wild type DT104 strain and the acrB mutant, respectively, and were not calculable for the tolC mutants or the DT204 strains because of a too small number of dead chicks. In contrast to the acrB mutants, the tolC mutants were unable to colonise the organs, and were not detected in the faeces of most chicks. The colonisation levels of the acrB mutants were the same as those of the wild-type strains. Thus, TolC but not AcrB appears to be essential for multidrug-resistant S. Typhimurium DT104 and DT204 colonisation of chicks, which correlate well with their respective roles in resistance to detergents and bile salts. TolC could therefore be a better target than AcrB for the development of efflux system inhibitors.

UR086 BioAgresseurs, Santé, Environnement, Institut National de la Recherche Agronomique, Tours-Nouzilly, France Campylobacter, one of the leading cause of human gastroenteritis, is reported worldwide to be increasingly resistant to antibiotics. Apart from target mutations, an efflux mechanism (CmeABC efflux system) has been described. By sequencing the whole operon of a resistant strain, we found that, in contrast to CmeA and CmeC, the CmeB sequence greatly differs (22%) from that of the NCTC 11168 strain. The objectives of this work were to design a PCR-RFLP method to study the diversity of this multidrug transporter in several representative strains of Campylobacter jejuni and Campylobacter coli (isolated from human, poultry or pig) and to examine its utility as a typing method. Twenty-three strains were included in the analysis. The entire cmeB gene was amplified by PCR and digested by eight restriction enzymes. A comparison of the restriction patterns was made to determine the diversity of the transporter sequence (at the nucleotide and protein levels). Eighteen different overall patterns were obtained. The same discrimination could be obtained by associating only half of the enzymes. A single HinfI-HaeII digestion was sufficient to discriminate two-third of the strains. Three pairs of identical patterns (including one human and one poultry grouping together) were observed. Overall, the strains showed 79-97% of homology except one poultry strain with less than 30% of homology. Differences were localized all over the sequence and also concern the characteristic functional motifs of the transporter. Of the twenty-eight potential restriction sites, two and five were respectively conserved in all or all except one of the strains. In conclusion, in contrast to its Salmonella and Escherichia coli AcrB homolog, a high diversity was observed in the cmeB multidrug transporter gene of both Campylobacter jejuni and Campylobacter coli. This could be of importance in targeting this pump to combat resistance. Furthermore, the PCR-RFLP designed in this work could be a cheap and easy-to-perform method to compare isolates of these bacterial species. In addition, protein modifications that could have a functional significance (in the characteristic motifs involved in substrate recognition and energizing) were also observed.

body_text.text: The discovery of efflux pumps inhibitors (EPIs) capable to restore the antibiotic susceptibility of bacterial mutants overexpressing efflux, in particular multidrug resistance (MDR) systems, would be of major interest providing that they are devoided of toxicity at therapeutic levels. Among currently available EPIs, benzimidazole derivatives such as omeprazole are safely used since years as inhibitors of the eukaryotic proton pump in the treatment of gastric ulcers, but exhibit a moderate activity against bacteria. In this study, a series of new potential inhibitors was synthesized, based on some common features shared by different EPIs. In this series, five molecules (1a-1e), showing structural analogies with the benzimidazole proton pump inhibitors, were examined. Then, published methods investigating the bacterial efflux systems and their inhibition were tested, in order to delineate a strategy for EPI evaluation, using the following model: Staphylococcus aureus strain SA 1199B, overexpressing the MDR efflux pump NorA, as germ-test; norfloxacin as preferential substrate; and omeprazole as reference EPI. Antibiograms by the diffusion method in agar supplemented with the EPI at MIC/4, subsequent checkerboard assays combining the antibiotic and the EPIs, and finally HPLC measurements of antibiotic intracellular accumulation with or without EPIs were found to be a useful approach. Products 1a-1d appeared to be efficient by the diffusion test and the checkerboard technique ( FIC = 0.25, for optimal concentrations of 8 mg/l of norfloxacin and 64 mg/l of EPI). At these concentrations; the most promising molecule 1c increased the intracellular level of norfloxacin from 3 to 8 × 10 −9 ng/10 −6 cells; compound 1e gave poorer results. In comparison, omeprazole yieded to a FIC = 0.25, and increased the norfloxacin intracellular accumulation up to 12 × 10 −9 ng/10 −6 cells. Thus, our products actually acted as EPIs on the MDR efflux pump NorA, but further research is needed to obtain drugs more effective than omeprazole. However, our data allowed structure-activity relationship analysis that will help us to modify the design of our synthesis and throw some light on the mechanism of action of these inhibitors on bacterial efflux pumps.

body_text.text: The aim of this study was to determine the distribution and the antibiotic susceptibility patterns of the strains isolated from 15 to 65 years old females with community-acquired urinary tract infections. From October to December 2003, 10 French private laboratories consecutively collected 420 clinical strains with medical informations from an interview with the patient: fever, pregnancy, associated diseases, history of urinary-tract abnormalities, re-infection (3 months), previous antibiotic treatment or hospitalization (6 months). Escherichia coli was the most prevalent pathogen (80%) followed by Proteus mirabilis (4%), Klebsiella spp. (2%), other Enterobacteriaceae (4%), Enterococcus spp. (3%), Staphylococcus aureus (2%), Staphylococcus saprophyticus (2%) and Streptococcus agalactiae (2%). S. aureus was more often isolated in diabetic's patients. Susceptibility to antibiotics was studied for E. coli using determination of minimal inhibitory concentrations by the agar dilution method in a coordinating center. Results were interpreted according to the recommendations of the Comité de l'Antibiogramme de la Société Française de Microbiologie. The susceptiblity was 61% for amoxicillin (AMX), 93% for nalidixic acid (NAL), 97% for norfloxacin (NOR) and ciprofloxacin (CIP), 77% for cotrimoxazole (SXT), 99% for fosfomycin, gentamicin and cefotaxime. The susceptibility of E. coli was lower in case of previous treatment with ␤-lactam antibiotics for AMX (84% versus 95%, p = 0.02) et SXT (62% versus 81%, p = 0.02). In the same way, previous treatment with quinolones was associated with decreased susceptibility for NAL (84% versus 95%, p = 0.02) and SXT (62% versus 81%, p = 0.02). For the treatment of these urinary tract infections, fluoroquinolones represented 53% of the prescribed antibiotics, followed by ␤-lactam antibiotics (24%), fosfomycin (14%), cotrimoxazole (4%), furanes (4%) and nalidixic acid (1%). Single-dose treatment, three days and seven days or more treatments were respectively prescribed in 16, 12 and 73% of the cases. Urinary tract infections (UTI) acquired in the community, seldom complicated, are very frequent and require an empiric treatment protocol based in the antimicrobial susceptibility pattern to etiologic agents. Uropathogenic Escherichia coli are the more frequent bacteria causing UTI and a marker for to predict the evolution of resistance in the community. We have studied the isolation of E. coli and your antimicrobial susceptibility pattern in our area during the last 5 years. We identified 4685 strains from urine samples with significant counts using conventional methods and broth dilution for to establish MIC from several antimicrobials (Microscan, Dade Behring). We have evaluated the sensitivity to ampicillin (AM), amoxicillin-clavulanic acid (AC), nalidixic acid ( (75.1-73.9 ). One thousand and ten strains were resistant to fluoroquinolones (23.6%). In this group the percentages of sensitivity to other antimicrobials were substantially lesser: 16.3 (AM), 63.3 (AC), 39.2 (TMP/SXT), 90.1 (FOS), 74.9 (FD) and 75.1 (GM), presenting cross-resistance in several strains. body_text.text: Purpose: The management of UTI in patients (Pts) in extended-care facilities is challenging, because of the high prevalence of bacteriuria, difficulties in diagnosing symptomatic UTI, and evidence that antibiotic treatment (AT) of asymptomatic bacteriuria (AB) is rarely beneficial. This study aimed to (i) identify UTI and AB, and (ii) to evaluate the impact of an antibiotic management program.

body_text.text: Methods: From July, 2003 to June, 2004, all positive urine cultures (PUC) obtained from patients hospitalized in a geriatric hospital (180 beds) were included. AB and UTI were diagnosed, according to McGeer criteria (Am J Infect Control, 1991; 19:1-71) . AT instituted for UTI or AB were prospectively assessed, and suggestions for alternative AT were made, if needed, according to standard recommendations.

body_text.text: Results: 181 patients (254 PUC) were included (mean age, 85 ± 9 y). In 128 PUC (50%), clinical signs of UTI were present: fever (32%), painful urination (15%), other signs (1-4% each). Other 126 PUC were considered AB. AT was initiated in 98 Pts: 69/128 with UTI (54%) and 29/126 (23%) with AB (p < 0.001). The white blood count was significantly higher in Pts receiving AT (8.9 ± 3.4 versus 7.7 ± 3.3 G/l, p < 0.01). No other criteria differed between the two groups. Of the 98 Pts with AT, 55 (57%) initially received a fluoroquinolone, 11 (11%) ceftriaxone, 11 (11%) amoxicilline, 11 (11%) cotrimoxazole and 10 (10%) other drugs. Before intervention, AT was correctly given according to susceptibility results in 79/98 Pts (81%); ordered AT durations corresponded to recommendations (5-7 d for UTI and 10-14 d for pyelonephritis) in 70/98 (71%) AT. The occurrence of influenza infections during hospital stay is responsible for severe consequences in immunocompromised and debilitated patients. The virus can be introduced in the medical setting by patients, visitors and health care workers (HCWs). The best way to prevent the diffusion of influenza virus by HCWs is to recommend their annual vaccination. However, the vaccine coverage of HCWs against influenza is weak. The aim of this study was to evaluate the perception of influenza vaccination by HCWs and their knowledge of the risks linked to influenza in hospitals. A self-administered questionnaire including 24 short items was proposed to the HCWs of two French University Hospitals (Hôpital Edouard Herriot in Lyons and CHU de Saint-Etienne) by the hygiene referent nurses of each ward, by the Departments of Occupational Medicine and by electronic mail. From a total of 7973 questionnaires that were distributed, 2763 responses (34.6%) were obtained from HCW: 72.0% from care-giving personnel, 12.2% from medical personnel and 15.4% from other personnel without contact with patients. The mean age of the responders was 37.8 years. The overall vaccine coverage against influenza was 26.9%, with significant differences between the three HCW categories: 21.0% for care-giving personnel, 57.7% for medical personnel and 29.1% for other personnel (p < 0.001). The main reason for HCWs to get vaccinated was their own protection (24.5%) whereas the protection of patients was mentioned by only 17.5% of them. The fact that the vaccination was not mandatory was the first reason to refuse it (33.2%) whereas the fear of vaccine adverse effects was mentioned by only 17.0% of the non vaccinated HCWs. A total of 41% of the responders mentioned that influenza is not a nosocomial infection suggesting that they ignore that non-vaccinated persons are at risk to transmit the virus within the hospital. The objective of the study was to identify baseline characteristics predictive of an SVR in patients treated with Pegasys + Copegus.

Methods: 289 HIV-HCV coinfected patients received Pegasys 180 g/week plus Copegus 800 mg/day for 48 weeks in this randomized, multinational study. All patients were followed for 24 weeks after the end of the treatment. The SVR was defined as a single undetectable (<50 IU/mL) HCV RNA at the end of follow-up (week 72) by qualitative PCR (COBAS AMPLICOR HCV Test v.2.0). The factors considered in a stepwise multiple logistic regression analysis of prognostic factors for SVR included: age, gender, race, body surface area, HCV RNA titer, HCV genotype, histological diagnosis, ALT quotient, CD4 cell count and use of active antiretroviral therapy (HAART).

Results: The only significant independent factors associated with SVR in patients treated with Pegasys/Copegus were: HCV RNA ≤800,000 versus >800,000 IU/mL (p < 0.0001) and the HCV genotype non-1 versus 1 (p < 0.0001). At week 12, 204 of 289 patients (71%) had an early virological response (defined as undetectable HCV RNA (<50 IU/mL) or a ≥ 2 log 10 decline in HCV RNA), of whom 114 (56%) achieved an SVR. Conversely, only two of 85 patients (2%) without an early virological response at week 12 achieved SVR.

Conclusions: In patients with HIV-HCV co-infection treated with the combination of Pegasys/Copegus, infection with HCV non-1 genotypes and an HCV RNA titer ≤ 800,000 IU/mL had the greatest impact of achieving an SVR. Innate immunity is the first line of host defense against many infections, and previous studies have shown that some components of the response exert in vitro activity against bacteria and protozoa. We therefore tested cathelicidin (CAT), indolicidin (IND), ␤-defensin 1 (␤D1), lysozyme (LYZ), phospholipase A2 (PLA2), and phosphoinositol specific phospholipase C (PIPLC) for direct in vitro killing and ability to reduce infectivity of C. parvum sporozoites.

Methods: Sporozoites (8 × 10 6 /ml) were incubated (15 min) with 10 (g/ml of each compound, C. parvum neutralizing MAb 3E2, or medium. To assess infectivity, intracellular stages were quantified 24 h after inoculation of treated-sporozoites onto Caco-2 cells using a C. parvum-specific MAb and an automated immunofluorescence microscope. Non-specific toxicity of each compound for Caco-2 cells was assessed by LDH release.

Results: None of the compounds or MAb 3E2 was toxic for Caco-2 cells. LYZ did not modify the infection.

Conclusion: Cationic peptides and phospholipases warrant further investigation as potential anticryptosporidial agents. However, the reduction of sporozoite infectivity exerted by both phospholipases shows that viability assessment alone is not sufficient to identify potentially active compounds against C. parvum. B. bronchiseptica causes chronic respiratory infections in a wide range of animals but is rarely implicated as a human pathogen. B. parapertussis may cause a milder form of whooping cough. The complete genome sequences of B. bronchiseptica RB50 (5.3 Mb), and B. parapertussis 12,822 (4.7 Mb) have been published recently. Cloning experiments of the corresponding gene, bla BBR−1 , of B. bronchiseptica CIP102314 (reference strain) gave recombinant clones expressing a clavulanic-acid inhibited class A ␤-lactamase, BBR-1, with a pI value of 5.6 and a relative molecular mass of ca. 32 kDa. We sequenced also the gene bla BBR−1 of two clinical strains of B. bronchiseptica and of a reference strain of B. parapertussis CIP 63.33. In all cases, a same bla BBR−1 gene was found. BBR-1 shared 42 to 52% amino acid identity with the most closely related enzymes, the chromosomally encoded enzymes from Rhodopseudomonas palustris and Stenotrophomonas maltophilia. B. parapertussis was susceptible to all ␤-lactams except to cefoxitin whereas B. bronchiseptica was susceptible to amino-, carboxy-, ureidopenicillins, cephalothin and carbapenems but resistant to broad-spectrum cephalosporins, whereas reference strains of both species hydrolyze nitrocefin. Once cloned, the substrate profile of the non-inducible BBR-1 was that of a clavulanic-acid inhibited narrow-spectrum penicillinase. The ␤-lactamase BBR-1 hydrolyzed significantly benzylpenicillin, ampicillin, ticarcillin, piperacillin, at a lower level cephalothin whereas no activity was detectable against broad-spectrum cephalosporins and carbapenems. Since 1999, 10 Klebsiella pneumoniae and one Klebsiella oxytoca clinical strains producing inducible DHA-1 class C beta-lactamase have been isolated in the Paris area. The horizontal transfer of one plasmid carrying bla DHA-1 could be shown for seven of these strains. The aim of this study was to compare the genetic organization of bla DHA-1 in these eleven strains. By analogy with previous results obtained for K. pneumoniae Kp760 and Salmonella enteritidis KF92, both producing plasmid-mediated DHA-1 enzyme, primers were designed for genome walking by PCR mapping. When this methodology failed, either resistance to cefoxitin was cloned in pBKCMV, or GenomeWalker TM DNA walking was used for finding unknown DNA sequences adjacent to bla DHA−1 . For all strains of Klebsiella spp., the region mobilized from Morganella morganii including ampC and ampR genes was inserted upstream to second copy of 3 -Conserved Segment (3 -CS) of a complex sulI-type integron, like In6/In7. For three strains, the M. morganii region of variable length was inserted in a complex sulI-type integron; each of them had a different cassette genes profile. For one strain, the M. morganii region lay straight downstream to the common region (CR), like it was previously described for Kp760 or KF92. The CR includes an orf513 presumably coding for a recombinase involved in the mobilization of resistance genes. For two strains, between the CR and the M. morganii region, was inserted an additional 10 kb fragment, partially identical to sap (ABC transporter) and psp (phage shock protein) operon from Salmonella typhimurium LT2. The genetic organization of bla DHA was identical for the other eight strains, seven of them harboring the same plasmid. Surprisingly, despite the presence of a truncated 3 -CS adjacent to ampR, no integron element was found, neither int gene, nor orf513. Nevertheless, upstream to the M. morganii region lay a part of the fragment identical to S. typhimurium LT2 including the psp operon. The emergence of acquired DHA-1 Klebsiella spp. in the Paris area was partially due to horizontal spread of one plasmid. bla DHA seems to have been mobilized from M. morganii by several independent recombination events, most often in complex sulI-type integrons including a putative recombinase.

Polymorphism and drug-selected mutations in the HIV-1 Reverse Transcriptase gene in naive and treated patient isolates from the Seine-Saint-Denis district in France: differences between B and non-B subtypes The comparison of phenotyping and genotyping results obtained from HIV-1 isolates has allowed to define anti-Reverse Transcriptase (RT) treatment algorithms which can be deduced from the amino-acid sequence of the RT. However, most of the collected data were obtained from B subtype isolates, and only few publications are available concerning RT gene mutations in non-B subtypes. We have collected and analyzed the HIV-1 RT sequences of 49 naive patients (22 B and 27 non-B subtypes), and 638 treated patients (457 [71.6%] B and 181 [28.4%] non-B subtypes). On one hand, the sequences were interpreted according to Stanford "virtual phenotype algorithm". On the other hand, they were aligned and statistically analyzed in order to detect eventual subtype-related differences between RT sequence profiles. In the naive group of patients, 8/22 B subtype isolates displayed anti-RT resistance mutations. Two of these isolates presented mutations associated with resistance to AZT, 3TC, d4T, EFV and NVP, three to AZT, 3TC, and d4T, and one to 3TC. One isolate displayed the mutation M41L and another Y115F. Only 1/27 non-B subtype isolate displayed anti-RT resistance mutations (K70R, and Y115F). Moreover, a significant difference in the amino-acid substitutions was found between B and non-B subtype isolates at 4 positions including 184, 210, and 215 which are associated to drug-resistance. In the treated group, the Stanford virtual phenotype algorithm indicated a higher prevalence of anti-RT resistance in B as compared to non-B subtype isolates (59.6% versus 50.4%). Amino acid substitution analysis in the RT sequence evidenced a significant difference between B and non-B subtype isolates in 30 positions including six drug-resistance associated sites (41, 44, 67, 74, 115, and 210 ) even though the treatment regimen was similar in both B and non-B infected patients. Our results indicate that the amino-acid profile of B and non-B subtype isolates is different, either because of their natural polymorphism or as a result of treatment history. The high prevalence of resistance mutations in naïve B subtype isolates should encourage the systematic RT gene sequencing, in order to adapt treatment strategy to the virus. Our results suggest that treatment algorithms based on B subtype cohort studies may need modifications to be applied to non-B subtype isolates. Efforts should be considered to study each subtype independently.

CD4 cells count (flow cytometry) and HIV-1 viral load (Cobas Amplicor HIV Monitor V 1.5, Roche Diagnostic Systems) were assessed at baseline, 1 and 2 months of treatment, and then every 2 months. Early virologic response (1-2 weeks) was also evaluated.

Results: Thirty patients were included between April 2002 and June 2004 (26 males; six females; median age [range] of 40 [22-73] years). Most of them were asymptomatic: 24 in group A of 1993 CDC classification, 6 in group B and 2 in group C. At baseline, median (range) CD4 count was 230/mm 3 (69-425/mm 3 ), and median HIV-1 viral load was 4.9 log (3.14-> 5.89 log). Twelve subjects had CD4 < 200/mm 3 , and 15 had HIV RNA > 5 log. At 6 and 12 months (on treatment analysis), median viral load decrease was −3.24 log and −3.2 log, and 15/18 (83%) and 8/12 (67%) had viral load <50 copies/ml. Early virologic response was −1.66 log (median HIV RNA decrease after 1-2 weeks of treatment, 28 evaluable subjects). Median CD4 count increase was +85/mm 3 at 6 months, and +53/mm 3 at 12 months. Treatment interruptions (5/32 (16%)) for clinical side effects were seen (abdominal pain and nausea: 3; anemia: 2, probably due to ZDV). Only 1 renal deficit was observed, pre-existing to TDF therapy. During the first 12 months of treatment, 4 viral failures occurred, 1 with K65R mutation, 2 with M184V + 2 or 3 TAMS, and 1 with 2 TAMS. Two of them successfully changed the ARV treatment; the others remained on ZDV + LAM + TDF, with low viral loads.
Conclusion: Combination of ZDV + LAM + TDF in ARV naïve HIV-infected subjects induces a rapid and sustained HIV RNA decrease, associated with a good immunologic response, and is safe.

body_text.text: Clinical and virological follow-up of a cohort of HIV-1 infected patients receiving enfuvirtide Bienvenu B b , Krivine A a , Spiridon G b , Pietri MP b , Lebaut V b , Sicard D b , Lebon P a , Salmon D b , Launay O b . a Laboratoire de Virologie, Paris, France, b Service de Médecine Interne, Groupe Hospitalier Cochin-Saint Vincent de Paul, Paris, France Background: Enfuvirtide (ENF), an antiretroviral agent acting by inhibiting the virus-cell membrane fusion process, is now available in France; only few data regarding its clinical and virological efficiency have been shown.
Methods: Retrospective study of a cohort of HIV-1 infected pts who began ENF therapy between 11/2002 and 01/2004 at Cochin Hospital, Paris.

Results: The 16 patients (pts) included in the study (13 men and 3 women) had an advanced HIV-disease: 11 stage C, 1 B, and 4 A, and a median CD4 nadir at 45/mm 3 . They had previous exposure to a median of 12 antiretroviral drugs for a median duration of 9 years and their median genotypic sensitivity score was 2. At baseline, the median CD4 cell count was 121/mm 3 [5-320] and the median plasma HIV-1 RNA 52,700 copies/ml. ENF was given with an optimised regimen including a mean of 2.7 (S.D. ± 1.5) drugs, according to the results of the genotypic resistance test. Pts were individually educated for self-injections. Tolerance of treatment was good in 75% of the pts. Minor adverse events occurred in 25% of them (mostly injection-site reactions) that did not lead to discontinuation of therapy. Median duration of follow-up was 6 months. In 13 pts (81%), a response to therapy was observed since plasma HIV-1 RNA decreased by more than 1 log from baseline. Three pts experienced a viral rebound within 3 months, but in the other 10, the virologic response was sustained. Plasma HIV-1 RNA undetectability (<50 copies/ml) was reached by seven pts, and was sustained (>3 months) in five. In this group, the median CD4 cell count increase at M6 was 126/mm 3 . In only three pts, no virological response was observed. Analysis of resistance mutations in the HR1 region of gp41 in three of the six pts in virologic failure showed wild-type virus before treatment, and presence of described ENF-resistance mutations between M4 and M7: G36V + N42D in a non responder and V38A, G36V+V38A in two patients experiencing viral rebound.

Conclusion: ENF associated with optimised antiretroviral therapy showed sustained immuno-virologic efficiency and a good tolerance. In the event of virological failure, genotypic changes have been observed in the HR1 region of gp41. Their reversion after the ENF withdrawal, and their influence on the viral replication remain to be studied.

Incidence of and risk factors for hepatotoxicity associated with nevirapine in HIV-1 infected patients Background: Rash and hepatotoxicity are the most common and limiting toxicities of nevirapine (NVP). The objective of this study was to assess the incidence of and risk factors for developing hepatotoxicity within 12 weeks (w) after NVP initiation.

Methods: Two hundred pts enrolled in the VIZYR trial, a randomized, double blind, placebo-controlled trial showing no preventive effect of cetirizine on NVP-associated rash, had physical examination at study entry, and at weeks 2, 4, 8 and 12. Liver tests were performed at screening, and at weeks 2, 4 and 8. Trough NVP plasma concentrations were determined after 2, 4 and 8 w of treatment. Hepatotoxicity was defined as an increase of at least two-fold in serum alanine aminotransferase (ALT) or aspartate aminotransferase (AST) levels compared with baseline values and ALT and/or AST levels > 2.5 times the upper limit of normal (ULN), severe hepatotoxicity as an increase in ALT and/or AST levels > 5 times the ULN. Statistical analysis was performed using a logistic regression test to assess risk factors of hepatotoxicity.

Results: Twenty-six pts (13%) developed hepatotoxicity in a median of 21 days [8-55 days], including 17 pts with severe hepatotoxicity. Findings included fever (n = 7), cutaneous reaction (n = 6) including two pts with hypersensitivity syndrome, eosinophilia (n = 10); five pts had no clinical symptom. All pts experienced restoration of transaminases levels and resolution of clinical symptoms. Mean NVP plasma concentrations at 2 w did not differ between pts developing hepatotoxicity and others: 3.7 ± 1.6 versus 3.4 ± 1.7 g/mL, respectively. Multivariate analysis does not identify any predictive risk factor for hepatotoxicity.
Conclusion: Close monitoring of liver enzyme levels is recommended in all pts starting a NVP containing regimen. Eosinophilia appears to be associated with hepatotoxicity.

Documentation and validation of events before analysis is less standardized in the context of observational epidemiological studies than of clinical trials. back_matter.text: Background: The aim of this study was to characterize the extendedspectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL) produced by eight clinical isolates of Aeromonas caviae during an outbreak in an Intensive Care Unit.Methods: Eight isolates of A. caviae with a positive double-disk synergy test were collected from patients in the Intensive Care Unit in Colmar's hospital, France. A genotypic comparison of the strains was achieved by pulsed-field gel electrophoresis. Isoelectric focusing was performed with a detection of the beta-lactamase activity by an iodine starch procedure. For cloning experiments total DNA was extracted, partially digested by Sau3AI and ligated into pK18-BamHI digested. The ligation product was introduced in E. coli DH5à and the transformants were selected on kanamycin (20 mg/l) and ticarcillin (30 mg/l).Results: The six strains were clonally related. The bla PER-3 (pI about 5.4) was cloned on a 2.7 kb fragment. PER-3 differed from PER-1 by the following amino acid substitution: H129 to L129. bla PER-3 was located on a complex orf513-bearing integron as already described for some betalactamases.Conclusion: This report is the first description of an ESBL belonging to the PER family in A. caviae and confirm the spread of members of this family among different species.
